description.narrative: 2019 represented a year of consolidation in relation to CIVIC's organisational growth and special efforts were made to create and implement standard operating procedures, with particular focus on understanding the gaps in policies and processes across the organisation, especially between field offices and headquarters. CIVIC has reported many relevant and important achievements in 2019, of which a few are accounted for below: - In 2019, CIVIC continued to push for reforms within the UN peacekeeping structure in order to improve protection options for civilians. CIVIC successfully influenced the mandates of the peacekeeping missions in CAR, DRC, Soth Sudan and Mali. For example, CIVIC secured significant changes to the protection of civilians (POC) language in MINUSMA's (Mali) mandate when it was renewed in June. As a result, POC is a higher priority and the resolution has the most detailed language on civilian harm mitigation (CHM) of any peacekeeping operation mandate. CIVIC also specifically raised awareness on the critical role of strategic planners in peacekeeping missions. For example, in anticipation of the risk for budget cuts of the UN peacekeeping mission in CAR, CIVIC managed to mobilise Secretariat personnel to work to mitigate such risk. - CIVIC's work with civilian protection groups deepened and expanded in 2019. All community-based protection efforts reported positive outcomes in 2019, of which those in Nigeria and Afghanistan are the best documented. For example, as a result of interaction and dialogue between community protection groups and the military related to reintegration of former Boko Haram fighters in Bama in Nigeria, the reintegration process is now more inclusive which helps improve community buy-in for returnees. Community based activities also started in Iraq and Yemen during the year. - In 2019, there was also positive progress in relation to Civilian Harm Mitigation (CHM). For instance, CHM was institutionalized into the curricula of three Nigerian military educational institutions and 2,487 armed actors, members of the military, and other security force members were trained in Nigeria. - In Afghanistan, Nangarhar community members successfully negotiated with a local Taliban commander in the Nayzan district to halt the planting of new improvised explosive devices (IEDs) along public roads and to refrain from using civilian homes and properties as bases of operations for staged attacks against the national defense and security forces. During 2019, CIVIC also developed guidelines for future single-gender community working group sessions in Afghanistan, in order to allow women to discuss protection issues that may be too sensitive to bring up in front of male counterparts.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Det övergripande målet för "Kubaprogram 2018-2021" är att kubanska aktörer har stärkt sitt arbete att bidra till uppfyllandet av de grupprättigheter som man valt att fokusera på: kvinnors rättigheter, afrokubaners rättigheter och hbtqi-personers rättigheter, miljö/hållbar utveckling samt barn och unga.
Det finns två projektmål som handlar om att stärka kubanska civilsamhällesaktörer i sitt rättighetsbaserade arbete samt att ett urval av kubanska aktörer har ökat sin kunskap om tillämpning av grupprättigheterna.
Syftet är att bidra till en lokalt driven utveckling vilket kommer att genomföras genom kapacitetsstärkande stöd till främst civilsamhällesorganisationer men även andra aktörer. Metoder för att uppnå programmålen är institutionellt stöd, kapacitetsstärkande insatser, nationella och internationella utbyten samt dokumentation och studier. Ägarskap och delaktighet är centrala komponenter i programmet.
Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Support civilsociety organisations in Cuba

tag.narrative: 1.1 - By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.
1.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa den extrema fattigdomen för alla människor överallt. Med extrem fattigdom avses för närvarande människor som lever på mindre än 1,25 US-dollar per dag.
1.2 - By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.
1.2 - Till 2030 minst halvera den andel män, kvinnor och barn i alla åldrar som lever i någon form av fattigdom enligt nationella definitioner.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 The proposed project will support the different local government institute of Government of Bangladesh to improve environmental health and resilience of WASH-deprived urban poor living in slums and low income settlements. To achieve this goal, the expected outcomes of the project are: • WASH deprivation reduced among target communities through increased WASH awareness and access to climate/disaster resilient, community-based WASH services • Local governance in pro-poor WASH service delivery and coordination with other services in target cities and towns improved • WASH policies and strategies improved in favour of urban poor through evidence and advocacy

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Den växande befolkningen boende i slumområden som följd av framförallt den snabba urbaniseringstakten i Bangladesh, har idag en mycket begränsad tillgång till kvalitetssäkrad vatten- och sanitet. Avsaknaden av statlig vatten-, sanitet- och hygienreglering kombinerat med svaga leverantörer inom sektorn ökar bland annat befolkningens sårbarhet mot vattenburna sjukdomar och andra miljörelaterade risker kopplade till katastrofer och översvämningar. Bristerna inom vatten och sanitet har också en stor negativ inverkan på nutrition, hälsa och utbildning. Dessa specifika utmaningar som drabbar den fattiga befolkningen i urbana slumområden kräver lösningar på individ-, kommunal-, institutionell- och politisk nivå. WaterAids föreslagna insatser för att förbättra tillgängligheten till vatten och sanitet i vanligtvis försummade slumområden ligger i linje med övergripande mål i den svenska regeringens strategi att skapa förutsättningar för bättre levnadsvillkor för människor som lever i fattigdom och under förtryck. Insatsen tar en integrerad, tvärsektoriell ansats och kan genom detta bidra till synergier mellan Sidas resultatområden inom resultatstrategin för Bangladesh 2014-2020: i) demokrati, jämställdhet och mänskliga rättigheter, ii) bättre möjligheter för människor som lever i fattigdom iii) bättre miljö, begränsad klimatpåverkan och ökad motståndskraft och iv) förbättrad grundläggande hälsa. Både resultatstrategin och Sidas policyram för svenskt utvecklingssamarbete och humanitärt bistånd understryker vikten av tillgången till hållbara och resilienta vatten- och sanitetsinrättningar i dess betydelse för att förbättra grundläggande hälsa, särskilt mödra-l och barnhälsa, vilket är bevisat betydligt sämre i slumområden jämfört med icke-slumområden. Insatsens arbete med att förbättra vatten och sanitet hos vårdinrättningar samt att ge utbildning till primärhälso- och sjukvårdspersonal bedöms också bidra till att stärka vårdsystemen generellt. Den föreslagna insatsen kommer att fokusera på att på kommunal nivå hjälpa regeringen i Bangladesh och olika lokala myndigheter att förbättra miljö, hälsa och resiliens genom förbättrad vatten- och sanitet hos befolkning boende i slumområden låginkomstområden. För att uppnå detta mål är de förväntade resultaten av projektet: • Vatten- och santitetsbrister minskas bland målgrupper genom ökad vatten- och sanitetsmedvetenhet samt genom ökad tillgång till klimat- och katastrofresilienta samhällstjänster kopplade till vatten- och sanitet; • Lokal förvaltning vid leverans och styrning av vatten- och sanitet, vilket även samordnas med andra samhällstjänster i städer ska och har förbättrats med avseende på vatten och sanitet; • Strategier kopplade till vatten och sanitet skall förbättras till förmån för de fattiga i städerna genom evidensbaserat arbete kombinerat med juridiska medel. Sverige bidrar med 55 MSEK av insatsens totala budget på ca. 67 MSEK under perioden 2018-2022. Insatsen beräknas nå och gynna 450 000 innvånare boende i 170 olika slumområden i Dhaka, Chittagong och Khulna tillsammans med ytterligare tre städer i andra delar av landet.

sector.narrative: Basic drinking water supply and basic sanitation

tag.narrative: 3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.
6.b - Stödja och stärka lokalsamhällenas deltagande i arbetet med att förbättra vatten- och sanitetshanteringen.
6.b - Support and strengthen the participation of local communities in improving water and sanitation management.

description.narrative: This conclusion of performence has been developed at the end of the second year (January – December 2019) of five-year contribution with WaterAid. The project aim is to improve environmental health and resilience of WASH deprived urban poor living in slums and low income settlements in 3 big cities including Dhaka, Chattogram and Khulna and 3 municipal towns of Sakhipur, Saidpur and Paikgachha.The project is now in its third year and WaterAid Bangladesh with its implementing partners are working to achieve the planned targets in the three major areas – reduce WASH deprivation, system strengthening for pro-poor WASH services and updated WASH policies and strategies. During the second year, a total of 34,799 people (47% female) reached with safe water and 46,856 people (48% female) reached with improved sanitation facilities from low income communities, educational institutes and pavement dweller canters s in the project area. Consequently, 20 schools and 02 health centre were supported with WASH facilities as a part of sector integration. To ensure long-term sustainability of the constructed WASH facilities, in total 358 caretakers have been trained on operation and maintenance of WASH facilities. Moreover, project has developed contributory WASH fund mechanism where community and institutions deposit 10-20% of the total cost of the facilities depending on their ability. Over the reporting period 4.68 million BDT has been mobilized as local WASH fund which will be used for O&M of respective WASH facilities in the coming years. Along with construction/renovation of WASH facilities, hygiene was given extra priority throughout this period. During this reporting period, 60,807 people (63% female) was reached with handwashing messages at community and institutions. Additionally, separate sessions were organized specifically for women and adolescent girls through which 18,944 women and adolescents got orientation on MHM and 10,334 got on water safety plan. Apart from this, 959 handwashing facilities were installed at household and institutions through motivation and project support which helped 40,730 users to establish handwashing practice and influence their neighbours with similar need. Additionally, 67 campaigns and events were organized in communities and schools to observe, global handwashing day, world water day, world environment day, world menstrual day through engaging local governments, duty bearers and other sector actors for WASH promotion. Moreover, the project is continuing its support towards improving WASH access for pavement dwellers and city commuters. Partial operation and maintenance support to 30 public toilets recorded 3.06 million uses during the reporting period. This project has been supporting the construction of faecal sludge management (FSM) plant in Saidpur municipalities since last year which is constructing phase by phase. Beside this, scale up operation of another FSM plant in Sakhipur is ongoing smoothly. A total of 972 latrine pits/septic tanks were emptied during this reporting period following the WaterAid’s health and safety protocol and treated accordingly. As part of strengthening the Solid Waste Management (SWM) system, Saidpur municipality developed a city-wide solid waste collection plan for next three years. Under the plan, 907 waste bins have been distributed to the households of three ward of the municipality. Besides, 8 small entrepreneurs have developed through project support for providing solid waste management services in LICs serving 4,748 households. Through motivation, 1,552 households managing and disposing of child faeces safely.As a part of capacity building for pro-poor WASH service delivery, international training on rainwater harvesting and septage management, 52 learning visits, meetings and workshops have been organized for different duty bearers and others including project implementing partners. Along with these, the project coordinated with multi sectors such as education, health and agriculture to ensure sustainable WASH promotion through 105 meetings and workshops. Another significant advocacy work of WaterAid Bangladesh is that a key WASH Networks of Bangladesh as well as pre and post budget conference have been organised for influencing government to fill up the financial gap in WASH sector in order to achieve SDG6. WaterAid has been engaging with advocacy at the national level to sensitize relevant authorities on improved urban WASH policies and strategies including water quality, progressive tariff, resources allocation for LIC, waste management and urban rainwater harvesting through sector capacity strengthening and mass campaign. As a part of this, in continuation of the advocacy with WASA, the project has been actively participating in WASA central and zonal coordination meetings. 31 central and zonal coordination meetings were organized with WASA officials during the reporting period. As a result, 78 more water points have been legalised in the name of CBOs in last year. In line with the above and continued advocacy from WAB and sector actors, the government of Bangladesh approved the development of a National WASH Accounts for the water supply and sanitation sector in March 2019. Along with service delivery and advocacy initiatives, the project has few research plans on pro-poor WASH related issues. In collaboration with UNDP, CUP and CBOs of low-income communities have organized a national seminar on “Eviction and Housing Rights of Urban Poor” where a position paper on “Housing of urban poor” was presented. Another focused area of this project is sector capacity enhancement under which different trainings (rainwater and FSM), research works, and different events have been done during the reporting period. Along with the sector capacity, the project also gives priority to system strengthening which is done with education department and city corporation. In municipality areas, town and ward level coordination committees have been given capacitated to promote city-wide sanitation. The project prioritised in media campaign during this reporting period under which different campaigns were highlighted in media and a talk show called ‘Unnayan Rekha’ has been organised as well.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 This is an intervention for the continued support of MSEK 475 to the "UN Multi-Partnership Trust Fund" (MPTF) for Somalia in 2018-2019. In Decision 2016-002435, dated 30 June 2015, Sida decided to support MPTF 2015-2017 with an amount of 140 MSEK. Following the decision 52/16 from November 2016, an additional 33 MSEK was added and an additional 55 MSEK through decision 14/17, dated April 24, 2017 and finally 10 MSEK was added in Dwecember 2017 through decision 58/2017. Sida assess that the MPTF and the joint programs that Sweden contributes to delivers results despite some challenges that comes with implementation of programmes in a difficult context.
Somalia is one of the poorest countries in the world and is characterized by inequality. Recurrent humanitarian crises and armed conflicts pose challenging to the development of the country. Furthermore, Somalia is affected by climate change and recurring periods of drought. 2.3 million people have insecure food supplies and there are over one million internally displaced persons. Of a population of about 12 million, over 70% are poor and more than 40% live in extreme poverty. One of seven children dies before their first birthday; one of eighteen women die in childbirth; and only one in three persons have access to safe drinking water. Over 70% of Somalia's population is under thirty years and lack employment opportunities which leave many of them with few prospects for the future. Women are structurally discriminated and gender based violence is widespread. Somalia has the highest incidence of female genital mutilation in the world. Women also lack access to justice that can protect their interests. The lack of a formal and effective legal justice system in most parts of the country has led to extensive impunity. In 2017, Somalia was ranked as the most corrupt country in the world according to Transparency International.
However, a relatively peaceful political process for state building has begun. The increasing international support in recent years has contributed to progress in many areas. The implementation of the indirect parliamentary election held in the fall of 2016 with increased political representation of women in addition to the presidential elections in February 2017 followed by a peaceful change of power are particularly positive signs.
The MPTF was established in 2015 with Sweden as one of the first donors. The fund currently manages a total of USD 200 million. The two biggest donors are the EU followed by UK. So far, Sweden has contributed with 238 MSEK during the period and is thereby the third largest donor to the fund. During the period 2015-2017, Sweden has supported the central political processes (elections, constitution, parliament and the new federal state formation), the development of the judiciary, job creation for young people, and public administration. Furthermore, Sweden has provided support to the UN's core functions to enable effective implementation in a challenging context like Somalia. In addition, pilot support for the fund's so-called "national window", to use Somalia’s own country systems have been successfully supported to a prison rehabilitation facility, supplementing the above-mentioned legal aid program. Despite challenges on an overall level, it is Sida's assessment that these programs together deliver results.
Moreover, Sida assess that the MPTF is now fully established and that the programmes that are funded are implemented satisfactory. The international community has made significant commitments. Somalia has developed a National Development Plan (NDP) for Somalia 2017-2019. In addition, a Security Pact was adopted at the Somalia Conference held in May 2017 in London. The Security Pact sets out the roadmap for a Comprehensive Approach to Security, CAS. Hence, the UN has developed its own strategic plan (UNSF) for Somalia that reflects both the NDP and CAS. The MPTF is the main funding mechanism for UN support the implementation on the UNSF.
Sida assess that the MPTF continues to be relevant and appropriate mechanism to deliver support. Based on Sweden's development cooperation strategy for Somalia and the new Strategy to come, Sida proposes that the continued support to the MPTF shall be earmarked for the following thematic areas and for the programs decided in the framework of these: 1. Including policies, governance and federal state building, as well as reconciliation 2. Human rights, women, peace and security 3. Economic recovery and resilience 4. Reproductive, maternity and child health and rights
Within the area of Reproductive, maternity and child health and rights, 140 MSEK will be earmarked to UNFPA’s country programme for Somalia 2018-2020. For more information on the assessment of UNFPA as a strategic partner to Sida in Somalia, pleas se decision 28/2017, dated 2017-06-22. In addition, 60 MSEK shall be earmarked for the so-called "Enablers Program", which includes support for the UN Risk Management Unit, the UN department for Security, and the Resident Coordinator's Office (RCO), which is considered to be crucial for implementation of all development efforts in Somalia.
However, the MPTF is not only a financing mechanism but also constitutes a platform for donor coordination in a broader sense since it includes the major actors such as the EU, UK, US, NO, DE, and DK. At the same time, there is a trend that the EU and the UK are launching new bilateral programs in certain areas, while other donors such as DE will expand their support in favor of the MPTF. The MPTF is an important and a key instrument for cooperation between the international community and the Federal Government of Somalia to realize the overall development goals of sustainable peace and development in Somalia.
The MPTF will harmonize and align the significant resources that are channeled through the UN in Somalia and as such it is foreseen to a more effective international support for Somalia. If the international community, the FSG and other stakeholders cooperate to reduce the risks, it is Sida's assessment that objectives will be reached to a reasonable extent despite the complex context and the many challenges it entails.
The draft agreement follows that between the UNDP and Sida agreed template for the current form of cooperation. The new standard Standard Administrative Arrangement, SAA will regulate Sweden's contribution to the MPTF. The SAA will be signed by Sida and UNDP as the administrative agent. A Terms of Reference for the MPTF as well as a Memorandum of Understanding between all implementation UN partners are attached. Sida’s conditions in the contribution management rule are thereby fulfilled. Furthermore, a Memorandum of Agreement has been signed between the Government of Somalia and UNDP as an administrative agent.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen avser ett fortsatt stöd om 475 MSEK till "UN Multi-Partnership Trust Fund" (MPTF) för Somalia under 2018-2019. I beslut 2015-002435, daterat 30 juni 2015, fattade Sida beslut att stödja MPTF 2015-2017 med ett belopp på 140 MSEK. Ytterligare 33 MSEK tillsköts genom beslut 52/16 från November 2016 , samt ytterligare 55 MSEK genom beslut 14/17, från 24 april 2017 och slutligen 10 MSEK genom beslut 58/2017 från December 2017. Totalt har Sida utbetalt 238 MSEK under perioden 2015-2017. Sida gör bedömningen att MPTF och de program som Sverige bidrar till trots går tillfredsställande trots vissa utmaningar och levererar resultat i en svår miljö.
Somalia är ett av världens fattigaste länder och landet präglas av ojämställdhet och ojämlikhet. Återkommande humanitära kriser och väpnade konflikter utgör svåra utmaningar. Våld mot civilbefolkningen och grova brott mot mänskliga rättigheter är vanligt förekommande. Våldsam extremism utgör också en komplex utmaning för landet och den omgivande regionen. Problemet har också globala implikationer. Vidare påverkas Somalia av klimatförändringar och återkommande perioder av torka. 2,3 miljoner människor har osäker livsmedelsförsörjning och över en miljon är internflyktingar. Av en befolkning på ca 12 miljoner människor uppskattas drygt 70 % vara fattiga och drygt 40 % leva i extrem fattigdom. Ett av sju barn dör före sin första födelsedag; en av arton kvinnor dör under förlossning; och endast en av tre personer har tillgång till säkert dricksvatten. Över 70 % av Somalias befolkning är under trettio år och brist på sysselsättningsmöjligheter lämnar många av dem med få framtidsutsikter, vilket ytterligare bidrar till rekryteringsbasen för al Shabaab.
Kvinnor är strukturellt diskriminerade och könsrelaterat våld är utbrett. Somalia har den högsta förekomsten av kvinnlig könsstympning i världen. Kvinnor saknar dessutom tillgång till rättvisa som kan skydda deras rättigheter och tillvarata deras intressen. Bristen på ett formellt och effektivt rättssystem i de flesta delar av landet har lett till omfattande straffrihet. 2017 var Somalia rankat som det mest korrupta landet i världen enligt Transparency International.
Samtidigt har en relativt fredlig politisk process för återuppbyggnad av staten och dess institutioner inletts. Ett ökande internationellt stöd de senaste åren har bidragit till flera viktiga framsteg, exempelvis genomförandet av indirekta parlamentsval under hösten 2016, ökad politisk representation av kvinnor och presidentval i februari 2017 som ledde till ett fredligt maktskifte.
MPTF etablerades 2015 med Sverige som en av de första givarna. Fonden hanterar idag totalt 200 miljoner USD. De två största givarna är EU och UK. Det svenska bidraget på totalt 238 MSEK under perioden 2015-2017 perioden är det tredje största till fonden. Genom fonden har Sverige stött de centrala politiska processerna (val, konstitution, parlament och den nya federala statsbildningen), utvecklingen av rättsväsendet, jobbskapande för ungdomar, samt förvaltningsstöd. Vidare har Sverige lämnat stöd till FNs centrala funktioner som möjliggör närvaro, implementering och uppföljning i en svår och konfliktfylld kontext som Somalia. Dessutom har pilotstöd till fondens nationella fönster, där medel kanaliserades genom statsapparaten till en återuppbyggnad av ett fängelse i en av medlemsstaterna, vilket kompletter det ovan nämnda rättstödsprogrammet. Det är Sidas bedömning att dessa program sammantaget levererar resultat, trots stora utmaningar.
Sida gör även bedömningen att MPTF har etablerats fullt ut och fungerar tillfredställande, med ett betydande engagemang från bidragande givare, även om ett par givare börjar luta sig mot bilateral lösningar på vissa områden. Somalia har tagit fram en ny nationell utvecklingsplan 2017-2019 (National Development Plan - NDP). Därtill antog en säkerhetspakt vid den internationella Somalia-konferensen maj 2017 i London, vilken fastlägger färdplanen för genomförandet av en omfattande säkerhetsplan (Comprehensive Approach to Security, CAS) på federal och regional nivå. I ljuset av detta har FN tagit fram en strategisk plan (UNSF) som avspeglar NDP och CAS. MPTF är den främsta finansieringsmekanismen för FNs stöd till dess genomförande.
Sida bedömer att MPTF är ett fortsatt synnerligen relevant instrument som möjliggör ett flexibelt och ändamålsenlig stöd för att bidra till flera resultatområden i Sveriges strategi för utvecklingssamarbetet med Somalia. Sida föreslår att bidrag öronmärks kring följande tematiska områden och till de fondfinansierade FN program och projekt som beslutas inom ramen för dessa: 1. Inkluderande politik, samhällsstyrning och federal statsbyggnad, samt försoning 2. Mänskliga rättigheter, kvinnor, fred och säkerhet 3. Ekonomisk återuppbyggnad och motståndskraft 4. Reproduktiv-, mödra- och barnhälsa och rättigheter
Det finns två finansieringsfönster, ett FN-fönster där FN organisationer utgör implementerande part och ett nationellt fönster där Somalias regering genomför projekt i enlighet med ramverket för användandet av landets nationella system (use of country systems). UNDP är administrativ agent för hela fonden. Det svenska stödet kommer att gå till FN-fönstret av fonden, som sedan finansierar FN gemensamma projekt (UN Joint Programmes) som regleras genom Memorandum of Understanding mellan fonden och de implementerande FN organen. Medel utgår således från Sida, till UNDP som fondadministratör, och vidareförmedlas därefter till respektive ledande FN organ som ansvarar för programmets genomförande och uppföljning. Som fondadministratör, ansvarar UNDP för rapportering till givarna. Avstämningar sker i olika styrkomitteer på flera nivåer (givarsamordning tillsammans med Somalias regering samt på projektnivå) inom ramen för den etablerade samordningstrukturen (Somalia Development and Recontruction Facility- SDRF).
Inom området reproduktiv-, mödra- och barnhälsa och rättigheter kommer 140 MSEK öronmärkas till UNFPA:s landprogram för Somalia. (För fördjupad bedömning av UNFPA som strategisk parter i Somalia och av UNFPA:s landprogram 2018-2020, se beslut 28/2017, daterat 2017-06-22.)
Dessutom avses 60 MSEK öronmärkas till det så kallade "Enablers programme" som innefattar stöd till FNs riskhandteringsenhet, till avdelningen för säkerhet och trygghet, samt till Resident Coordinator's Office (RCO) vilket bedömds vara avgörande för alla utvecklingsinsatser i Somalia.
Avtalsutkastet följer den mellan UNDP och Sida överenskomna mallen för den nu gällande samarbetsformen. Det nya standardavtalet (Standard Administrative Arrangement, SAA) kommer att användas för att reglera Sveriges bidrag till fonden. Avtalet kommer att undertecknas av Sida och av UNDP som administrativ agent. En uppdragsbeskrivningen för MPTF samt ett Memorandum of Understanding mellan alla genomförandeparter är bilagda (utkast). Insatshanteringsregelns krav för avtal för SAA för FNs finansieringsfönster är uppfyllda. Vidare har ett Memorandum of Agreement ingåtts mellan FSG och UNDP som administrativ agent.
De juridiska förutsättningarna för att kunna lämna stöd även till det nationella fönstret diskuteras för närvrande mellan Sida/JUR och FN i New York. Om och när dessa diskusioner är avslutade kan ett eventuellt stöd till det nationella fönstret bli föremål för ett separat tilläggsbeslut.
MPTF harmoniserar betydande resurser som kanaliseras inom FN i Somalia och bidrar därmed till ett koordinerat internationellt stöd till Somalia. Trots många och allvarliga risker, är det Sidas bedömning att uppsatta mål kommer att nås till en rimlig grad om FN, deltagande givare och somaliska aktörer samarbetar för att minska dessa risker. Sverige och andra givare kommer att spela en viktig roll i detta avseende.
Det ska tilläggas att MPTF inte enbart utgör en finansieringsmekanism, utan fungerar även som en plattform för givarkoordinering i bredare bemärkelse och inbegriper de största givarna som EU, UK, USA, NO, DE, och DK. Fonden är därmed ett viktigt och centralt instrument för det internationella givarsamfundet och den somaliska regeringen i deras samarbete för att förverkliga de övergripande målen om fred och utveckling i Somalia. Samtidigt börjar EU och UK delvis initiera nya bilaterala program inom specifika områden, medan andra givare såsom DE kommer att utöka sitt stöd till MPTF.

Strengthening Women’s Capacities as Agents for Change in Peacebuilding, Reconciliation and Ending Violence Against Women Strengthening Women’s Capacities as Agents for Change in Peace-building, Reconciliation and Ending Violence Against Women programme is anchored on the recognition that gender equality is fundamental in achieving sustainable peace. The programme recognizes the imperative need to include women and girls in the political, legal, economic and social spheres to advance gender equality. It contributes to the National Development Plan (2017-2019) pillars on peace, inclusive politics, security and rule of law. The programme is further linked to the UN Strategic Framework (2017-2020) for Somalia and its Strategic Priority 1 (Deepening federalism and state-building, supporting conflict resolution and reconciliation, and preparing for universal elections) and Priority 2 (Supporting institutions to improve Peace, Security, Justice, the Rule of Law and safety of Somalis). The programme is being executed by UN Women as the lead UN entity in coordination with the Federal Government of Somalia (FGS) through the Ministry of Women and Human Rights Development (MOWHRD). Key Objective The objective of this programme will be to create an enabling environment to promote participation and inclusion of women in decisions and efforts related to conflict prevention and resolution, women’s safety and security. The programme will also aim to contribute to the elimination of violence against women (EVAW), and to promote the socio-economic recovery of women. Expected Outcomes (i) Women’s leadership and participation in peacebuilding, conflict prevention and reconciliation is increased at community, federal and state levels. (ii) Positive coping mechanisms are promoted for marginalized women and girls at risk of involvement in violent extremism. (iii) Positive social norms, attitudes and behaviors are promoted at community and individual level to raise awareness on and prevent elimination of violence against women and girls.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.

description.narrative: This CoP presents the final assessment of the Joint Programme on Youth Employment Somalia (YES) which was implemented from September 2015 to December 2019. The activities of YES were implemented by 5 Participating United Nations Organizations (PUNOs) and these are: FAO, ILO, UNDP, UN-Habitat and UNIDO in collaboration with the Federal and local government authorities, local NGOs and the private sector. The lead ministry for the YES was the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (MoLSA).The donors supporting the program were Denmark, Italy, Sweden and Switzerland. The program was implemented in Mogadishu, Jubaland (Kismayo), Puntland (Bosaso), Somaliland (Hargeisa and Berbera), South West (Baidoa, Hudur) and Hirshabelle (Beletweyne). By the end of 2019, the youth employment program has created a total of 11686 short term and long-term youth jobs. Of these, 7236 were short-term Cash for Work (CFW) jobs and 4450 were long-term jobs from Skills Training and Value Chain interventions. The program reached a total of 12577 direct beneficiaries of which 7580 were male and 4998 were female. National ownership by the government was demonstrated by full involvement and cooperation of MOLSA and other government structures including development of a national employment strategy and finalization of the national labor force survey data sets including Somaliland. Within this activity period (Jan-Dec 2019), the key results reported are: 1. 1,334 unemployed young people received long-term employment, having set up 70 microenterprises or obtained jobs in construction, fishing, and renewable energy. 2. 863 youth received short-term employment opportunities through labour-intensive and apprenticeshipinitiatives. 3. In fish value chain development, 140 young fishers became self-employed and generating incomes for their households of around 1,000 members in Bossaso, Kismayo and Berbera. Having acquired technical and entrepreneurial skills as well as having access to 10 fish processing facilities, micro-grants and business development services, young fishers established 24 fishing cooperatives/micro-enterprises in Bossaso (12), Kismayo (6) and Berbera (6). 4. Additionally, 120 fishing families, with around 900 members, received 40 fiberglass reinforced fishing canoes, in Mogadishu, Bossaso, Berbera, Kismayo, Baidoa and Beletweyne. 5. Regional Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point (HACCP) guidelines on seafood safety and export were developed for Jubaland, Puntland and Somaliland. Over 150 representatives of the governments, fishery associations and businesses were oriented in the new regulations. 6. At least 30 at-risk youth became selfemployed having set up their own businesses in Hudur in South-West State while 75 at-risk youth improved their skills in market-oriented vocational trades and entrepreneurship having completed psycho-social counselling, literacy and numeracy sessions. 7. Seven hundred and ninety-six young people graduated from various training programmes, using a combination of skills training and on-the-job work experience to construct and rehabilitate various infrastructures in youth training centres and ministries in Kismayo, Baidoa, Dhobley, Beletweyne and Mogadishu. 8. An additional 384 youth improved their skills in solar panel installation and maintenance and entrepreneurship in Mogadishu, Baidoa and Kismayo. As a result, over 52 households and public facilities were provided electricity in the cities through the installation of solar panels. 9. The National Employment Policy (NEP) was developed and approved by the FGS Council of Ministers. A roadmap for the NEP implementation was developed which resulted in the development of a Somalia Employment Programme. The overall findings of the entire program are as follows: - The YES programme had a well-designed strategy that was both strategically aligned and relevant to the Somalia context and national development priorities. - According to the final evaluation, gender was fairly well mainstreamed within the programme. The programme reached a total of 12577 direct beneficiaries of which 7580 were male and 4998 were female. - The program had a strong national ownership by the government at federal and member state levels, which was demonstrated in the commitment and involvement of the government in program implementation. - The JPYES has left tangible program assets on the ground and this is commendable. The government demonstrated strong ownership of program assets by undertaking to maintain and sustain all the program assets – the roads and youth centres, training halls, etc. that were rehabilitated during the program life cycle. While there were positive findings from the programme, some challenges were also identified in the final evaluation. - The technical sustainability of the government was undermined by low capacity building effort and unclear roles for the different line ministries engaged in the programme. - The program design was based on a joint programming approach, but it was implemented on an individual basis, and it could not benefit from the efficiency benefits of synergy and collaboration of the joint approach. The roles of each PUNO were not clearly outlined, agreed upon and documented, including the targets and outcomes expectations. - The program lacked a strong PMU that could steer all the joint parties into focusing and achieving a common goal. It takes a robust and well-resourced PMU to accomplish a program’s vision and to achieve program targets. - Bureaucratic financial management processes during program implementation were also identified in contributiong to long delays in disbursing funds for timely program implementation, and this created time inefficiencies which prolonged program implementation.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 IOM Zimbabwe 2017 - 2020. Human Rights Monitoring, Protection and Promotion
COVID-19 IOM Zimbabwe 2017 - 2020. MR - Övervakning, skydd och främjande

description.narrative: New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The goal of the support is to strengthen the monitoring and protection of human rights in Zimbabwe by providing support to a number of key organizations engaged in human rights monitoring, awareness raising for the public regarding their human rights, legal support and litigation assistance to people affected by human rights violations, as well as organizations dealing with the care of persons exposed to politically motivated violence and torture

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Det övergripande målet med insatsen är att bidra till stärkta mänskliga rättigheter för utsatta grupper och personer i Zimbabwe. Stödet syftar till att stärka övervakning och skydd av mänskliga rättigheter i Zimbabwe, genom att ge stöd till ett antal nyckelorganisationer som arbetar med MR-övervakning, utbildning för allmänheten om deras mänskliga rättigheter, rättsligt stöd och hjälp för de som utsätts för MR-övergrepp, samt organisationer som arbetar med vård av personer som utsatts för politiskt motiverat våld och tortyr. Förväntade resultat (outcomes) är: 1. Ökad tillgång till information för medborgare/rättighetsbärare (flickor och pojkar, kvinnor och män i Zimbabwe) om sina mänskliga rättigheter och stärkt kapacitet för att skydda dessa, från grästrotsnivå upp till nationell nivå. 2. Stärkt kapacitet för effektivt samarbete mellan medborgargrupper/civila samhället och de som är skyldiga att respektera, främja, skydda och uppfylla dessa rättigheter (ansvarstagare). 3. Stärkt övervakning av respekt för mänskliga rättigheter. 4. Stärkta system för hantering av övergrepp mot mänskliga rättigheter.
Projektet genomförs av International Organization of Migration (IOM) i Harare tillsammans med ett nätverk av civilsamhällesorganisationer. Projektet bygger vidare på ett pågående stöd till IOM från EU. EU kommer med stor sannolikhet att bidra med ytterligare medel till projektet från och med mars 2018.
Ambassaden bedömer att den föreslagna insatsen uppfyller ett flertal resultat under strategin för Sveriges utvecklingssamarbete med Zimbabwe 2017-2021. Insatsen relaterar också till följande mål för FNs globala mål för hållbarutveckling; Mål 3 Hälsa och Välbefinnande, Mål 5 Jämställdhet, och, framförallt, Mål 16 Fredliga och Inkluderande samhällen.

description.narrative: Cumulatively the project has reached 52,989 individuals affected by human rights violations, a total of 8,916 individuals where assisted by the project during 2019. Some of the outputs achieved by the intervention in the project period are: - A total of 1,831 victims of human rights violations were assisted with medical, legal advice, shelter and psychosocial support. - Zimbabwe Lawyers for Human Rights (ZLHR) handled 48 cases, and 4 out of 48 cases received positive judgments. - Zimbabwe Peace Project (ZPP) and Zimbabwe Lawyers for Human Rights (ZLHR) submitted a written and verbal submissions to the UN Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food; based on the reports submitted by monitors throughout the year. This contributed to some of the recommendations made by the Special Rapporteur for aid to be distributed fairly. - The October 2019 ZPP Monthly Monitoring Report (MMR) reported on the issue of artisanal miner armed terror gangs “MaShurugwi” assaulting and murdering citizens, and received great traction in the media, increasing the deployment of armed police in Kadoma and Chegutu to protect citizens. - ZimRights and its trained human rights defenders, in a bid to promote inclusivity and political tolerance, successfully lobbied the District Administrator for Masvingo Province and Masvingo Central Member of Parliament through the Minister for Masvingo Provincial Affairs for the return of donated goods (an ambulance, beds, and blankets) to a local clinic. - The Zimbabwe Human Rights Commission (ZHRC) conducted eight Mobile Legal Aid Clinics in Mt Darwin, Guruve, Mbire, Tsholotsho, and Gokwe respectively during the reporting period. The Mobile Clinics improved access to legal assistance and advice on various human rights issues affecting them.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Women for Women's Human Rights-New Ways (WWHR) har ansökt om finansiellt stöd om 24 MSEK från Sida för genomförandet av organisationens strategiska aktiviteter under perioden 2018-2022. Insatsen ämnar bidra till hållbara förändringar som stödjer kvinnors mänskliga rättigheter. WWHR anser att hållbara förändringar endast kan ske när en mental förflyttning skett på samhällelig nivå, en kritisk massa deltar, och när dessa sammanfaller med stärkta och förbättrade normativa system på nationell och internationell nivå. Hållbar förändring nås genom: • Kunskapsproduktion och spridning: Skapa utrymmen för att stärka utbytet mellan aktivism och forskning för att generera kunskap och spridning av denna genom publiceringar och andra audio, visuella, tryckta och digitala medel. • Kapacitetsbyggande, medevetandehöjande och kvinnors stärkta egenmakt: Kapacitetsbyggande, medevetandehöjande och stärkandet av kvinnors egenmakt genom utbildning och stöd till kvinnor, kvinnorättsorganisationer, aktivister, ungdomar, professionella utövare, statliga institutioner och andra rättighetsbaserade organisationer. • Påverkansarbete: Deltagande påverkansarbete på lokal, nationell, regional och internationell nivå för att skydda, genomdriva och förbättra juridiska rättigheter, säkerställa att nödvändiga mekanismer används, och öka medvetenheten för att säkerställa att kvinnors mänskliga rättigheter realiseras. • Nätverkande: Nätverka och verka i solidaritet med kvinnorörelsen och andra rättighetsbaserade rörelser genom insatser för att främja kapacitetsbyggande, medvetandehöjande, kvinnors egenmakt och påverkansarbete. Dessa domäner faller in i varandra samt sker i cykler, och är därför inte att förstå som en linjär process. Insatsen totala budget omfattar 24 MSEK för en femårsperiod.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Women for Women's Human Rights-New Ways (WWHR) has applied to Sida for funding of 24 million SEK to carry out their strategy activities of the NGO during the period 2018-2022. The intervention aims at sustainable change and transformation rather than short-cut and transitory solutions to women’s human rights issues. WWHR believes that for sustainable change to occur, a mental shift needs to take place at the societal level, reach a critical mass, and converge with strengthened and improved normative systems at the national and international levels. Sustainable change results from: • Producing and sharing knowledge: Creating enabling spaces to link action-research with knowledge generation and sharing, and disseminating the generated knowledge through publications and other audio-visual, published, and digital means, • Building capacity, raising awareness, and women’s empowerment: Building capacity, raising awareness, and promoting women’s empowerment through education and support programs with women, women’s rights organizations, activists, youth, practitioners, state institutions, and other rights-based organizations, • Advocacy: Taking part in joint and participatory advocacy work at the local, national, regional, and international levels by protecting, enforcing, and improving legal rights, putting the necessary mechanisms into practice, and raising awareness to ensure that women’s human rights are realized. • Networking: Networking and solidarity with all levels of the women’s movement and other rights-based movements through efforts to build capacity, raise awareness, promote women’s empowerment, and advocacy. All these domains feed one another and work in a cycle, rather than as a linear process. The intervention’s total budget is 24 million SEK for 5 years.

Women for Women’s Human Rights – New Ways (WWHR) is a women’s NGO in Turkey that aims to promote women’s human rights, equality and non-discrimination at national and international levels. Since its foundation in 1993, WWHR has become a well known NGO in its area. More than two decades of work on activism, advocacy and networking, WWHR has worked for making contributions to various legal reforms, increasing women’s awareness and enjoyment of their rights in Turkey, advancing sexual and bodily rights in Muslim societies and also worked on women’s human rights at the UN level. Recipient of the 2007 Gruber Foundation International Women’s Human Rights Prize, WWHR had held special NGO Consultative Status with the Economic and Social Council of the UN since 2005. In June 2017, WWHR embarked on a new strategic planning process to identify how it can continue to fulfill its mission to spread rights awareness from a feminist and women rights perspective at the local, national, regional, and international levels; contribute to women’s equal, influential and unobstructed participation in life and advocate for the protection and strengthening of women’s human rights. Based on the lessons learned from the previous Strategic Plan executed over the past five years (2013-2017) and the current sociopolitical situation in Turkey, WWHR aimed to develop an overall strategic framework and roadmap for its operations in line with the Results Assessment framework. The concrete activities and operations proposed with the current Strategic Plan covers the upcoming five years (2018-2022), and is planned to be regularly reviewed and revised on the basis of Annual Operational Plans. This new strategy is an updated version of the previous strategies and by this strategy, WWHR's mission is set as "to spread awareness of feminist rights at the local, national, regional and international levels; contribute to women’s equal, influential, and unobstructed participation in life; and advocate for the protection and strengthening of women’s human rights." This proposal of WWHR is aligned with the latest developments Turkey that has been through such as increased conservatism, shrinking space, Syrian conflicts/migration, challenges/limitations created by conservative central government and local administrations, Feto and PKK operations, State of Emergency (SoE), increased terror attacks by ISIS and PKK, closure of NGOs by the government through decrees, miltary involvement wwith YPG forces in Syria etc. It would be also important to mention here that WWHR is very much dependent on international funding in particular to Sida due to their feminist stance against government's (unofficial) conservative ideological agenda (gender equity/justice).

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: WWHR, has continued to perform as expected in 2020 despite the challenges created by Covid. It is assessed from the annual report and from the review meeting that WWHR has managed to realise many of their activities, when necessary adapted the activities to online and cancelled/postponed when needed. THEMATIC AREA 1: RAISING RIGHTS AWARENESS, CAPACITY BUILDING, AND WOMEN’S EMPOWERMENT: Aid in the empowerment and build the capacity of various beneficiary groups and institutions on rights awareness through trainings, awareness-raising programs, and training publications/materials. Under this area of work WWHR continued to coordinate and provide support to its trainers working at municipalities and local women’s organizations and training participants until the outbreak of the pandemic. Many planned activities had to be suspended and WWHR had to revisit and revise its 2020 activity plan. The activities had to be implemented online and they organized virtual meetings with trainers and partners; publicizing the recordings of these meetings. WWHR as a response to the pandemic developed a new training tool—the Online Gender Equality Seminars (GESs)— which is comprised of 7 new seminars on gender equality and rights; and realized a three-day Online Orientation Training. WWHR, very importantly, continued to establish new collaborations with new partners ranging from municipalities to private sector companies and women’s organizations. During the period between January and mid-March, nine Gender Equality Seminars were implemented in the field, through online implementation with cooperation with Istanbul Metropolitan Municipality. Additionally, in the framework of project led by Family Planning Foundation with Istanbul Metropolitan Municipality, WWHR conducted trainings on economic and social rights with the participation of Roma women in Istanbul. In fall 2020, WWHR signed Partnership Protocols with two more municipalities, which increased the number partnerships to 16 municipalities. The activities that required face-to-face contact could not be implemented due to Covid-19 restrictions and official bans. THEMATIC AREA 2: LOCAL, NATIONAL, REGIONAL, AND INTERNATIONAL ADVOCACY: Advocacy, policy development, and awareness-raising to develop new legislation, and monitoring and strengthening current legislation that will safeguard women’s human rights and the achievement of gender equality in Turkey and worldwide, by supporting the formation of connections between national and international processes and the establishment of solidarity networks. WWHR and many other women’s rights organisations have been challenged by the rising global and national attacks against gender equality, LGBTI+ rights, and human rights. It is reported by WWHR that the pandemic period has made advocacy efforts even harder to obtain the results and to affect the decision makers both at national and multilateral levels. However, it is assessed that WWHR has made use of all channels of online communication and advocacy methods to mobilize international institutions against these attacks. It is observed by Sida that WWHR’s contribution to these efforts at national level have been highly effective is spite of the pandemic. WWHR has also shown great effort to make the interlinkages between feminist & LGBTI+ organizing and awareness raising in the face of all attacks, carrying all relevant advocacy events such as workshops, and panels online to discuss, strategize, and advocate on women’s rights. THEMATIC AREA 3: RESEARCHING, PRODUCING AND SHARING FEMINIST KNOWLEDGE AND STRATEGIES: Continue to be a reliable resource that offers knowledge and expertise on women’s human rights, and develop, disseminate, and create space for sharing feminist knowledge and strategies, especially against increasing negative trends, both at national and international levels. It is reported by WWHR that, due to the pandemic, all face-to-face activities & communication had to be cancelled throughout the year, and new ways & channels are established, and the existing ones had to be improved to be able to reach the target groups and raise their voice. During this period, WWHR has managed to realise a remarkable success on the social media and has shown a great effort to increase number of followers to implement effective digital campaigns, to reach more people, to improve new communication strategies and to adapt the new normal. Especially developing an influential communication strategy during the Istanbul Convention campaign led to great results in Thematic Area 3. WWHR reached more than 3 million people by organizing effective social media campaigns, production of brochures videos, visuals & animation films, dissemination of visibility materials.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

sida:strategy.sida:title: Reform cooperation with Eastern Europe, the Western Balkans and Turkey 2014-2021
sida:strategy.sida:titleSV: Reformsamarbete med Östeuropa, Västra Balkan och Turkiet 2014-2021

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Det övergripande syftet med insatsen är att förbättra levnadsvillkoren för befolkningen på landsbygden med speciellt fokus på kvinnor och minska fattigdomen i denna målgrupp genom: 1) Ökad inkomst för små lantbrukare 2) Ökad resiliens i produktionen för småskaliga lantbrukare mot klimatförändringar 3) Förbättrade arbetsvillkor för män och kvinnor för minskad social sårbarhet 4) Ökad kvinnlig egenmakt 5) Förbättrat deltagande i publik planering och styrandemekanismer
Insatsen är ett samarbete mellan Schweiziska utvecklings institutionen (SDC) och Sveriges Ambassad i Bolivia (härefter "Ambassaden") där genomförandeparten är Swisscontakt, en global NGO med kontor i La Paz. Insatsen baseras på habilitering och koordinering av aktiviteter där olika marknadsaktörer ger människor på landsbygden, med fokus på kvinnor, ökad tillgång till finansiella och icke finansiella tjänster, teknik och service. Aktiviteterna väntas bidra till ökad inkomst framförallt i försäljning av livsmedel, främjandet av miljövänliga marknadsmodeller (såsom ekologiska produkter och hållbara produktionssystem) och en ökad ekonomisk, social och miljömässig resiliens.
I utvecklandet av programmet och analys av kontext har Swisscontakt tillsammans med Svenska Ambassaden arbetat med den multidimensionella fattigdomsanalysen (MDPA) tillsammans med en "Market for the poor" (M4P) ansats och dessa två ansatser kombinerade kommer att genomsyra genomförandet av insatsen.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The main objective of the project is to improve the living conditions of the target population and thereby reducing their levels of poverty. Specific objectives of the project are to: i) increase the net incomes of productive family units, ii) increase their resilience towards climate change, iii) improve their working conditions (employment/self-employment), and reducing their social vulnerability, iv) enhance the empowerment of women, and v) improve participatory public planning and management mechanisms.
The Project will have five planned components: - Development and access to product markets - Development and access to non-financial services markets, inputs and technologies - Development and access to financial products and services - Favorable context for social and economic development - Women´s empowerment
The contribution is a co-financed between The Swedish Embassy in La Paz (The Embassy) and the Swiss Development Cooperation in Bolivia and the implementing partner is Swisscontact, a global NGO with three offices in Bolivia.
The intervention is based on the facilitation of coordinated actions where the different system markets actors can bring financial and non-financial services, supplies, technology in accessible and inclusive conditions to rural families (with emphasis on women). Those interventions should allow more and better incomes for the sales of their products in a more environmental friendly business model, lowering at the same time their risk. Swisscontact has together with The Embassy been using the multidimensional poverty analysis approach combined with the markets for the poor approach in the development of the programme and in the analysis of context and identification of target groups. These two approaches will be implemented throughout the programme.

tag.narrative: 1.1 - By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.
1.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa den extrema fattigdomen för alla människor överallt. Med extrem fattigdom avses för närvarande människor som lever på mindre än 1,25 US-dollar per dag.
1.2 - By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.
1.2 - Till 2030 minst halvera den andel män, kvinnor och barn i alla åldrar som lever i någon form av fattigdom enligt nationella definitioner.
13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.

5.4 - Erkänna och värdesätta obetalt omsorgs- och hushållsarbete genom att tillhandahålla offentliga tjänster, infrastruktur och socialt skydd samt genom att främja delat ansvar inom hushållet och familjen, i enlighet med vad som är nationellt lämpligt.

5.4 - Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family as nationally appropriate.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

description.narrative: Results on the main indicators of the project as of December 2020 show that, more than 24 000 UPF, 50% women (cumulative figure from January 2018 to December 2020) have accessed goods and services facilitated by the project; 10,536 UPF have increased their net income, more than 20 000 men and women have improved their self-employment, 8,661 UPF improved their strategies (measures) to adapt to climate change, 6,061 women have developed capacities and improved conditions that allow their empowerment in the prioritized territories and 1,179 women in other territories. Another important results of the project was its capacity to answer rapidly and efficiently to the pandemic in different ways. This was possible largely due to to large network of actors tied to the project. The project could support the food chains, local authorities in logistics and organisation to distribute food and to organise alternative marketplaces during lock-down. The project also facilitated life insurances including cause of death from COVID, through the innovation fund it impulsed the development of respirators by UMSA that could be used at intensive care units in hospitals during the pandemic. The project supported the communication and information campaigns in different local languages in relation to COVID.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 TROCAIRE- Peace through gender equitable and resilient communities in Ituri
COVID-19 TROCAIRE- Peace through gender equitable and resilient communities in Ituri

description.narrative: Given the Ituri context of instability trough displacement, lack of women’s empowerment, SGBV and gender inequality, the project proposes to address issues of women’s participation in informal and formal decision-making. These processes include those where conflict dynamics are influenced and discussed and around protection from SGBV and equitable access to land. To create an enabling environment for this to take place in Mambasa and Djugu, Trócaire aims to empower women economically, so that they can have the time and space to engage more meaningfully in the social empowerment work and protection from SGBV that the project will be supporting. Trócaire’s empowerment approach aims at strengthening individual and community capacities to engage with duty bearers and to influence plans and policies that directly affect their lives. A conflict sensitive approach will be applied throughout the project so that Trócaire activities and partners will be enabled to promote peace and contribute to reduced levels of destructive and violent conflict in target zones. The overall goal of the project is to contribute to peaceful and gender equitable communities in Mambasa and Djugu Territories, Ituri Province, DRC. 3 long term outcomes have been identified which the project will aim to reach: Women, particularly young women are socially and economically empowered to participate in both conflict and peace-related formal and informal decision-making processes at all levels;Women, girls and boys are free from violence and its associated risks ;Civil Society Organisations working on gender equality and women’s rights are strengthened and deliver on their objectives. A total of 16,000 people (11,200 women and 4,800 men) are being targeted by the proposed project. This figure is calculated based on 4,000 households benefiting from the proposed interventions within Djugu and Mambasa Territories. This program will cover 27 villages including 13 in Djugu and 14 Mambasa. These villages have already been supported by Trócaire in humanitarian and livelihood, and this intervention will continue to build on and consolidate its work. In Mambasa, Trócaire has been working with IDPs and host communities in Mambasa territory through food, NFI and WASH interventions while in Djugu, it has worked since 2010 targeting vulnerable women in a context of recurrent ethnic conflicts and limited accessibility.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Det föreslagna projektet ifrån Trocaire kommer att lyfta frågor kring kvinnors deltagande i beslutsfattande processer, såväl informella som formella. Detta inkluderar processer där konflikt är en faktor samt kring frågor som rör skydd från könsbaserat våld och jämställd tillgång till land. För att skapa en miljö där detta ska kunna ske avser Trocaire att stödja kvinnor ekonomiskt. Syftet med ett ekonomiskt stöd är att kvinnor ska kunna frigöra tid och möjlighet att engagera sig mer i det sociala arbetet för att stärka kvinnans roll och minska dess utsatthet för könsbaserat våld.
Trociares mål om ökat kvinnligt deltagande syftar till att stärka individers och gruppers förmåga att engagera sig och att påverka planer och policys som har direkt inverkan på deras liv.
Ett konfliktmedvetet tillvägagångssätt kommer att tillämpas för projektet så att Trocaires aktiviteter och dess partners kan främja fred och bidra till ett samhälle med mindre våld och konflikter.
Det övergripande målet för projektet är att bidra till fredliga och jämställda samhällen i områdena Mambasa och Djugu i Ituri-provinsen i DRK. 3 långsiktiga resultat har identifierats som projektet har som mål att uppnå:
1. Kvinnor, särskilt unga kvinnor, är socialt och ekonomiskt stärkta för att delta i konflikt- och fredsrelaterade beslutsprocesser på alla nivåer; 2. Kvinnor, flickor och pojkar är fria ifrån våld och våldsrelaterade risker; 3. Civilsamhällsorganisationer arbetar med jämställdhetsfrågor och kvinnors rättigheter stärks enligt uppsatta mål.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Trócaire's proposed project will address issues of women’s participation in informal and formal decision-making processes including those where conflict dynamics are influenced and discussed and around protection from SGBV and equitable access to land. In order to create an enabling environment for this to take place, Trócaire aims to empower women economically, so that they can have the time and space to engage more meaningfully in the social empowerment work and protection from SGBV that the project will be supporting.
Trócaire’s empowerment approach aims at strengthening individual and community capacities to engage with duty bearers and to influence plans and policies that directly affect their lives. A conflict sensitive approach will be applied throughout the project so that Trócaire's activities and partners will be enabled to promote peace and contribute to reduced levels of destructive and violent conflict in target zones.
The overall goal of the project is to contribute to peaceful and gender equitable communities in Mambasa and Djugu Territories, Ituri Province, DRC. 3 long term outcomes have been identified which the project will aim to reach:
1. Women, particularly young women are socially and economically empowered to participate in both conflict and peace-related formal and informal decision-making processes at all levels; 2. Women, girls and boys are free from violence and its associated risks ; 3. Civil Society Organisations working on gender equality and women’s rights are strengthened and deliver on their objectives.

tag.narrative: 16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Despite the challenging context, the project’s overall performance was satisfactory. The project reached in the first year more than 5,100 direct beneficiaries (see Annex 3) and was able to meet fully 7 out of the 10 outcome targets planned. During the reporting period the project supported 1,200 programme participants (women: 821, men: 379) with livelihoods inputs ranging from goats, seeds, tools, tree seedlings and integrated fish farming. This was accompanied by training, practical demonstrations, innovative farmer field school sessions and exchanges visits in order to strengthen the capacity of the programme participants on best practices in agro-pastoralism based on agro-ecological principles. At community level an intensive process of engaging local structures and civil society to take an active role in the development of local development plans has started. Village Development Committees were re-activated or created, CSOs concertation frameworks and citizens oversight spaces were established and training of these bodies have commenced to develop a roadmap to formulate community developments plans and operational plans. Community awareness-raising meetings were also conducted on women’s rights to access to natural resources, particularly land. 21 new protection committees were set up and together with existent structures trained on SGBV prevention, paralegal aid, psychosocial care and referral pathways. The strengthening of these structures was crucial, and committees demonstrate gradual progress in capacity development. In order to increase the economic independence of SGBV survivors, WAAFs, women at risk, and IDP, 54 Mutual Solidarity groups (MUSOs) have been set up of which 33 are trained and equipped in the 27 project villages. 1,080 members have joined, including 756 women and 324 of their spouses/male family members. 26 MUSOs and 8 individuals have simplified business plan in place and accompaniment took place to 13 income generation activities (IGA) by 7 women and 5 men (e.g. sale of salted fish, breeding of pigs and production of palm oil).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
