description.narrative: The main objective of the intervention is to enhance the inclusiveness of the intra-Syrian talks in Geneva. During the period in question such talks have not resumed, therefor no CSSR activites directly aimed att increasing civil society's participation the talks have been possible. The possibility, and even likelyhood of this, was part of Sida's risk assessment when deciding on an extension of the support to CSSR. However, the Civil Society Support Room has engaged in other activities aimed at strenthening the advocacy of Syrian civil Society towards primarily the UN system and wider international community and feeding in their concerns to the talks taking place outside the framework of the UN-system ("Astana-track"). In November 2018 the UN Office of the Special Envoy organized consultations in Geneva with 29 Syrian participants in various capacities who were given the possibility to feed their cinoncerns so the UN Special Envoy prior to his participation in the upcoming talks in Astana. Following this, the OSE in December 2018 held regional talks in Jordan and Lebanon with the aim of broadening the network of Syrian civil society participants as well as to collect views from these on the future of CSSR (especially given the bleek outlook for future intra-Syrian talks within the UN framework).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Grand Challenges Africa at AESA
COVID-19 Grand Challenges Africa at AESA

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 African Academy of Sciences (AAS) har hos Sida ansökt om 98,4 miljoner SEK för att genomföra programmet Grand Challenges (GC) Africa under perioden 2018-07-01 till 2023-06-30.
GC Africa är ett program som har målsättningen att stödja innovationer som ska bidra till att hitta lösningar för Afrikas utmaningar med att nå de Globala målen för hållbar utveckling. Det grundläggande konceptet bakom alla GC program är finansiering av innovativa idéer riktade mot specifika frågeställningar utan krav på preliminära resultat. GC Africa placerar konceptet i ett afrikanskt sammanhang och definierar frågeställningar/utmaningar relevanta i den afrikanska kontexten och programmet riktar sig specifikt mot afrikanska forskare verksamma vid universitet och organisationer baserade på den afrikanska kontinenten.
Programmet GC Africa har sin bas på Alliance for Accelerating Excellence in Science in Africa (AESA), ett programinitiativ grundat av AAS och organisationen New Partnership for Africa’s Development med syftet att tackla Afrikas utmaningar inom hälsa och utveckling. AESA har etablerat och driver olika program för att stödja forskare och forskning i Africa samt utveckla akademisk ledarskap och initiativ till innovationer. Sidas avtalspartner kommer att vara AAS, en ny partnerorganisation för Sida.
Den planerade totala budgeten för GC Africa programmet är ca. 246,5 miljoner SEK (28 miljoner USD) varav ca 86,5 miljoner SEK (9,85 miljoner USD) är finansierade av Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, Institute Pasteur och South African Medical Research Council. AAS har en pågående satsning att hitta fler givare till programmet, bland annat ska afrikanska regeringar och filantroper förmås att bidra. Av Sidas stöd till GC Africa kommer ca. 65,4 miljoner SEK att vidareförmedlas till forskningsprojekt.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The African Academy of Sciences (AAS) has applied to Sida for funding of 98,4 million SEK to contribute to the Grand Challenges (GC) Africa program during the period 2018-07-01 until 2013-06-30.
The GC Africa program aims at supporting the creation of innovations targeting developmental challenges preventing African countries from attaining the Global Goals for Sustainable Development. The basic concept of all GC programs includes grant support to research projects responding to pre-defined challenges not requiring extensive preliminary data. GC Africa has adapted this concept to the African context and established a program open to African researcher based at African universities and institutions and addresses challenges specific to African development needs.
GC Africa is a program of the Alliance for Accelerating Science in Africa (AESA) that is a programmatic platform founded by the AAS and the organization New Partnership for Africa's Development with the aim to address Africa's health and development challenges. AESA has established and drives different programs to support researchers and research projects in Africa and to develop academic leadership and innovations. Sida will enter into agreement with the AAS, a new partner organization for Sida.
The envisaged total budget of the GC Africa program is approximately 246,5 million SEK (28 million USD), out of which 86,5 million SEK (9,85 million USD) have been contributed by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, Institute Pasteur and the South African Medical Research Council. The AAS is in the process of attracting additional funders to the program and is approaching African governments and philanthropists. Of Sida’s support to the GC Africa program approximately 65,4 million SEK will be forwarded to research projects.

The overall objective of the intervention is to promote Africa-led scientific innovations to help countries better achieve the Sustainable Development Goals by awarding seed and full grants to the continent’s most impressive solutions.

tag.narrative: 9.5 - Enhance scientific research, upgrade the technological capabilities of industrial sectors in all countries, in particular developing countries, including, by 2030, encouraging innovation and substantially increasing the number of research and development workers per 1 million people and public and private research and development spending.

9.5 - Förbättra forskningen och industrisektorernas tekniska kapacitet i alla länder, i synnerhet utvecklingsländerna, bland annat genom att till 2030 uppmuntra innovation och väsentligt öka det antal personer som arbetar med forskning och utveckling per 1 miljon människor liksom de offentliga och privata utgifterna för forskning och utveckling.

9.b - Stödja inhemsk teknikutveckling, forskning och innovation i utvecklingsländerna, inklusive genom att säkerställa en gynnsam policymiljö för exempelvis industriell diversifiering och förädling av råvaror.

9.b - Support domestic technology development, research and innovation in developing countries, including by ensuring a conducive policy environment for, inter alia, industrial diversification and value addition to commodities.

Stöd till FN:s Human Rights Monitoring Mission i Ukraina
Support to the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU)

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Syftet med insatsen är att förbättra tillsynen på området mänskliga rättigheter (MR) i Ukraina, och då särskilt övervakning och dokumentering av våld och övergrepp som sker som konsekvens av konflikten i de östra delarna av landet. Insatsen syftar till att öka medvetenheten kring människorättsbrott bland relevanta ukrainska och internationella aktörer samt stärka deras kapacitet att identifiera och reagera på kränkningar av de mänskliga rättigheterna.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The aim of the intervention is to improve monitoring of human rights in Ukraine, in particular monitoring and documentation of violence and violations taking place as a consequence of the armed conflict in the Eastern parts of the country. The intervention aims at increase awareness of human rights violations among relevant Ukrainian and international actors and strenghten their capacity to identify and react to human rights violations.

The aim of the programme is to improve the observance of human rights in Ukraine, particularly in respect of violations and abuses stemming from the Russian aggression. The programme will aim at raising awareness of human rights violations among Ukrainian stakeholders, the UN system and the broader international community and at developing the capacity of local stakeholders to identify and address human rights violations.

description.narrative: The United Nations Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) continued to remain the major reference point on the human rights situation and violations of humanitarian law in Ukraine. HRMMU continued to monitor, report and advocate on the human rights situation through its office in Kyiv, as well as field offices in Donetsk and Luhansk (in armed group-controlled territory); and in Kharkiv, Kramatorsk, Mariupol and Odesa (in Government-controlled territory). In accordance with General Assembly (GA) resolution 68/262, HRMMU also monitored remotely, produced reports and advocated on the human rights situation in the Autonomous Republic of Crimea and the city of Sevastopol, Ukraine, temporarily occupied by the Russian Federation. Information, findings, analysis and recommendations were shared with national stakeholders and the international community, serving as a basis to inform and shape responses in addressing human rights violations. HRMMU’s findings and analysis have been used at a high level in the peace processes (Trilateral Contact Group in Minsk and Normandy Four), in the OSCE Permanent Council in Vienna, at the Security Council, and the Human Rights Council. HRMMU’s work has been instrumental in shaping strategic response mechanisms, including as foreseen in the Partnership Framework between the Government of Ukraine and the United Nations for 2018-2022, where HRMMU drafted its human rights component. In 2019, HRMMU delivered and reached its programmatic targets as planned, despite a changing political environment. Compared to the initial 2019 results framework, there were only two noteworthy changes during the reporting period, with one related to the inclusion of additional activities aimed at raising awareness, countering misconceptions and hate narratives and encourage acceptance and inclusion of the LGBTQI community, including among police officers of the National Police of Ukraine. The second was to assess the human rights impact of the conflict in the east of Ukraine on the enjoyment of economic and social rights of Ukrainians, especially in conflict-affected areas. All other activities and interventions were in line with programmatic and operational plans. MAJOR RESULTS AND ACHIEVEMENTS Protection, monitoring, documentation, and selected follow-up 337 new cases of human rights violations, including violations of international human rights and international humanitarian law were registered in OHCHR’s Human Rights Database in 2019 for future accountability, based on more than 595 interviews (of which over 39 per cent were with women). HRMMU monitored 469 trials, visited 69 places of detention and took 1,411 follow-up actions, reflecting the efforts, in particular of field teams, to gather additional information to corroborate allegations of human rights violations from interviews, and to engage in advocacy interventions for the protection of victims. 140 people (138 men and 2 women) detained arbitrarily were released following HRMMU advocacy. HRMMU completed 112 monitoring missions throughout Ukraine in 2019, including 18 missions to the administrative boundary line with Crimea. HRMMU recorded and corroborated 167 civilian casualties (27 killed and 140 injured) that occurred in 2019. Furthermore, HRMMU corroborated an additional 234 civilian casualties that occurred in 2014-2017. In 2019, conflict-related civilian casualties decreased by 40 percent compared with 2018 and reached their lowest levels for the entire conflict period HRMMU civilian casualty recording, reporting and advocacy – in coordination with national and international partners – contributed to the continued decrease of civilian casualties. The Mission’s focus on life-saving activities in eastern Ukraine, including a wider ‘protection by presence’ effort, was a contributing factor. HRMMU was able to reach victims and witnesses of violations; remote sites, shelled areas, grey zones, hotspots, checkpoints and vital civilian infrastructure; and interact with duty bearers, in a timely manner. The life-saving component of HRMMU’s work benefitted an estimated 10,000 civilians residing in the conflict zone. For the first time since the outbreak of the conflict, a State policy for remedy and reparations to civilian victims of the conflict was discussed in Parliament Following OHCHR/HRMMU advocacy coordinated with, and amplified by, national and international partners, the Parliament developed legislation to provide remedy and reparation for deaths and injuries of civilians, and for the loss of property, including housing, which could lead to a comprehensive State policy of remedy and reparations to civilian victims of the conflict. This is a long-standing HRMMU recommendation. Enhanced freedom of movement across the contact line (both for persons and goods) HRMMU's advocacy, combined with awareness-raising through its monitoring and reporting, contributed to the Government of Ukraine’s adoption in August 2019 of a resolution regulating the movement of individuals and transfer of goods across the contact line, with consideration of comments and suggestions that HRMMU and partners had provided. The resolution prescribes the establishment of a list of goods prohibited for transfer, to replace the list of goods allowed for transfer; and that children below 14 would be able to cross the contact line without passports. Registration of births and deaths of Ukrainians residing in armed group-controlled territory Following OHCHR/HRMMU’s advocacy, in coordination with other UN agencies, on 23 October 2019, the Cabinet of Ministers approved regulations introducing an administrative procedure for the registration of births and deaths occurring in territory controlled by self-proclaimed ‘republics’. This was a longstanding HRMMU recommendation supported by UN agencies working in Ukraine, as the UN worked as one to advocate on the issue of the registration of births and deaths of Ukrainians residing in armed group-controlled territory. Reduced quasi-automatic pre-trial detention in conflict-related cases in Ukraine Regarding the administration of justice, HRMMU’s advocacy succeeded in reducing the quasi-automatic use of pre-trial detention in conflict-related cases. This success was possible due to long-term (years-long) advocacy, by repeating recommendations disseminated through different channels and to various audiences, notably to legal professionals through two widely used online legal databases and a periodical for lawyers. Increased proper classification of hate crime incidents in Ukraine HRMMU continued its advocacy for the proper classification of hate crimes under article 161 of the Criminal Code throughout the implementation period. During the 20 June 2019 meeting between HRMMU and the Head of the National Police, the latter informed HRMMU that the police had changed its approach to the investigation of hate crimes. In response to UN Human Rights recommendations, the police have started gathering statistics, which indicate that cases of hate crimes had increasingly been classified as such compared with 2018. It is worth noting that in parallel, the overall number of the incidents decreased. Legal gaps in the definition of rape and sexual violence identified in the OHCHR/ HRMMU report addressed through amendments to the Criminal Code of Ukraine HRMMU advocacy, coupled with technical assistance, allowed HRMMU, together with UN Women, to address some of the gaps in the legal definition of rape and sexual violence identified in the 2017 OHCHR/HRMMU report on conflict-related sexual violence, through amendments to the Criminal Code of Ukraine, which entered into force in 2019. Protection from conflict-related human rights violations such as torture and ill-treatment, SGBV, incommunicado detention and assistance to 650 individuals 650 individuals – victims, family members and other persons affected by grave conflict-related human rights violations such as torture and ill-treatment, sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV), incommunicado detention and more, received legal assistance from civil society organisations (CSOs) supported by UN Human Rights. Renewal of the Social Cohesion Campaign HRMMU contributed to the renewal of the UN in Ukraine’s social cohesion campaign, updating two out of four briefing notes (on the need for the Government of Ukraine to ensure payment of pensions and the registration of births and deaths for people living in armed group-controlled territory) and providing comments to the other two (on freedom of movement and IDP inclusion). Furthermore, as part of the UN’s humanitarian work, HRMMU analysis supported the development of joint rapid response to address the disruption of basic services in the conflict-affected areas, together with OCHA, IOM, UNHCR, UNICEF and WHO. Addressing and preventing conflict-related sexual violence included in the national action plan on Security Council Resolution 1325 on Women, Peace and Security HRMMU’s follow-up advocacy jointly with UN Women contributed to the inclusion of measures to address and prevent conflict-related sexual violence in the overall national action plan on the realization of UN Security Council Resolution 1325 on Women, Peace and Security. Reports/briefing notes produced in 2019 Briefing note on accountability for killings and violent deaths during Maidan protests, including discussion of main impediments to bringing perpetrators to account and ensuring justice for all victims (19 February 2019). Thematic report on civic space and fundamental freedoms ahead of the presidential, parliamentary and local elections in Ukraine in 2019-2020 (12 March 2019). The report and advocacy based on HRMMU’s report, e.g. a G7 statement before elections calling for effective investigations of attacks by extreme right-wing groups, contributed to the fact that the Presidential elections were held in a peaceful, competitive and largely inclusive manner. 25th report on the human rights situation in Ukraine, covering 16 November 2018 to 15 February 2019, marking the five-year anniversary since the Government invited UN Human Rights to Ukraine. Key issues highlighted included arbitrary and prolonged detention, systemic use of torture and ill-treatment, and lack of access to justice, as well as impunity. Civilian casualties were down during the reporting period, but civilians living on both sides of the contact line continued to suffer. The report also welcomed the transfers of pre-conflict prisoners from territory controlled by self-proclaimed ‘Donetsk people’s republic’ and by self-proclaimed ‘Luhansk people’s republic’. In Crimea, HRMMU continued to document violations of international human rights and international humanitarian law. Early warning note on human rights concerns ahead of the first round of the presidential elections in Ukraine, which took place on 31 March 2019. The note was shared with UN Human Rights’ headquarters in Geneva, as well as the Resident Coordinator, who channelled it to the UN’s headquarters in New York, as early warning. Briefing note on accountability for killings and violent deaths on 2 May 2014 in Odesa (published on 2 May 2019). HRMMU held a press event presenting its views on the key impediments to bringing perpetrators to account and ensuring justice for victims. 26th report on the human rights situation in Ukraine (published on 13 June), covering the period of 16 March to 15 May 2019. Key issues highlighted included the effect of the conflict in eastern Ukraine on the civilian population, as well as torture and ill-treatment, issues with the administration of justice and impunity, notably for attacks on prior peaceful assemblies and minorities. The report also highlighted concerns relating to the lack of regular, unimpeded confidential access to all places of detention for international monitors in territory controlled by self-proclaimed ‘republics’. In Crimea, HRMMU continued to document violations of international human rights and international humanitarian law. HRMMU launched the report with a live-streamed press statement by the Head of the Mission, simultaneously translated into Ukrainian and sign language, followed by a launch event for civil society and representatives of embassies and international organizations. 27th report on the human rights situation in Ukraine (published on 17 September 2019), covering the period of 16 May to 15 August 2019. Key issues highlighted included the effect of the conflict in eastern Ukraine on the civilian population, as well as torture and ill-treatment, and issues with the administration of justice and impunity. The report also highlighted concerns relating to the lack of regular, unimpeded confidential access to all places of detention for international monitors in territory controlled by self-proclaimed ‘Donetsk people’s republic’ and self-proclaimed ‘Luhansk people’s republic’. In Crimea, HRMMU documented violations of international human rights and international humanitarian law. The press launch by the Head of the Mission was live-streamed and simultaneously translated into Ukrainian and sign language. It was followed by a launch event for civil society and representatives of embassies and international organisations. HRMMU prepared the first report of the Secretary General on the human rights situation in Crimea, pursuant to resolution 73/263 – published in August 2019 and presented to the General Assembly in October 2019. The 28th report on the human rights situation in Ukraine, covering the period from 16 August to 15 November 2019 (published on 12 December 2019), highlighted that while political efforts to end the conflict continued, the civilian population residing close to the contact line experienced daily hardship due to ongoing hostilities, resulting in the continued degradation of their socio-economic rights. People living in remote communities close to the contact line that are considered “isolated”, due to the disruption of road infrastructure, internal checkpoints, the contact line, and insecurity, continued to experience difficulties accessing social benefits and essential public services, such as healthcare, medicines, and education. HRMMU circulated eight updates (non-papers) on conflict-related civilian casualties (civcas) among key national and international stakeholders in 2019. HRMMU also provided over 20 ad hoc briefs (oral and written) on civilian casualties at the request of various UN agencies and national and international partners.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 SALAR 2018: Local governance and basic services in Syrias neighbouring countries
COVID-19 SKL 2018: Lokal samhällsstyrning och samhällstjänster i Syriens grannländer

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Sida har erhållit en ansökan om stöd till projektet Resilience in Local Governance (RESLOG) som ska implementeras i Libanon och Turkiet. Projektet syftar till mer hållbara och motståndskraftiga lokala samhällsstyrningssystem i dessa länder för att skapa fredliga och inkluderande strukturer och som på ett effektivt sätt och på mer jämlika villkor förser människor med samhällstjänster. Ansökan baseras på den förstudie som Sveriges kommuner och landsting (SKL) genomfört under 2016-2017 i Jordanien, Libanon och Turkiet. Med denna studie som underlag fattades under 2017 ett beslut att påbörja en inceptionsfas i Libanon och Turkiet och att utveckla ett fullständig projektansökan med förslag på aktiviteter, budget etc. Mot bakgrund av underlag i form av den feasibilitustudie som genomförts och erfarenheterna av inceptionsfasen beslutar Sida att stödja genomförande av RESLOG under perioden 1 december 2018 till 31 december 2020 med 71.500.000 MSEK.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Sida has received an application from the Swedish Association of Local Authorities and Regions (SALAR) for the project, Resilience in Local Governance (RESLOG): Lebanon and Turkey. The overall objective of the Project is sustainable and resilient local governance systems in Lebanon and Turkey, which are peaceful, inclusive, and provide equal and effective services to people. The application is based om the feasibility SALAR has conducted in Jordan, Lebanon, and Turkey in 2016-2017. After the feasibility study, Sida and SALAR agreed to commence an inception project in Turkey and Lebanon including the development of a full project proposal for Sida approval, establishment of project organisations, as well as implementation of selected activities. With the feasibilitystudie as a basis and the experiences of the inceptionphase Sida decides to support RESLOG during the period 1 December to 31 December 2020 with the amount of 71.500.000 SEK.

The intervention aims at enhanced policy framework, improved dialogue, and strategic capacity for sustainable and resilient local governance in Turkey and in Lebanon in communities specially affected by the Syrian crisis. The project has a planned implementation period of 28 months – from September 2018 to end of December 2020 – as this is the endpoint for the Sweden’s Regional Strategy for the Syria Crisis strategy. It is especially in the first strategic activity area where RESLOG belongs. It reads: Strengthened resilience, human security and freedom from violence, with a focus on livelihood opportunities, increased access to public services and reduced gender-based violence. The global objective of the project is: Sustainable and resilient local governance systems in Lebanon and Turkey, which are peaceful, inclusive, and provide equal and effective services to peopleSpecific goal in Turkey Enhanced policy framework, improved dialogue, and strategic capacity for sustainable and resilient local governance in Turkey.Specific goal in Lebanon: Strengthened municipal governance, service provision, and area-based coordination in the Akkar governorate. Specific geographical focus areas: In Lebanon, RESLOG will be implemented in the Akkar governorate in the north of the country and in Turkey the project will work in two distinct geographical areas demarcated through the Regional Unions of Municipalities of Marmara and Çukurova – both with significant numbers of Syrians refugees.

description.narrative: The activities of the project (implementation phase) just started at the beginning of 2019, as a continuity of the results achieved during the inception phase. The project establishment in Lebanon was more challenging than in Turkey, as the local context in Akkar is complex, especially considering the pressure for services due to the high numbers of immigrants/refugees. In addition to the fact that Lebanon is also a new country for SALAR operations. The activities in Turkey has advanced quicker due to the experience of SALAR in the country added to the well-organized municipal system of Turkey. This first period of activities is related with the establishment of offices, signing MoU with the federation of municipalities in the areas of intervention, capacity building workshops to majors and municipality officials, and coordination and networking with relevant stakeholders. In Lebanon solid waste management and public procurement are key subjects. In Turkey the key subject is related to digitalization of the information related to strategic planning for integration. Gender mainstreaming, capacity building, environmental awareness and conflict prevention are cross cutting objectives in both countries. There is no reporting agreed for this period (first reporting will be submitted in March 2020) and therefore no results are officially reported, but during the biannual meeting carried out on September 23 this year SALAR stated that the project is reaching results as planned. Highlighted results were capacity building related to public procurement and public private partnership building in Akkar, and strategic planning regarding integration on Marmara and Cukorova. SKL also underline advances in networking with relevant stakeholders in the areas of intervention as a relevant progress result of the project.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Marie Stopes Zambia, MSZ, has a theory of change with an ultimate goal to improve women's health and reduce maternal mortality in Zambia. This is expected to be achieved through two main results: 1) Increased use of contraception and access to safe abortions among poor and marginalized women and girls; and 2) Enhanced SRHR policies and successful implementation of these. MSZ has formulated three results to be achieved within the framework of this specific intervention: 1. Increased access to modern high-quality contraceptives and safe abortion services, especially for marginalized women and adolescents. 2. Increased awareness of contraception and safe abortion through education and information to decision-makers at community level; to poor and marginalized women and young people. 3. Enhanced advocacy work to create an improved legal and policy environment for contraception and access to safe abortion. MSZ programme activities thus include direct healthcare services in close collaboration with central and local health authorities, support to MSZ's health clinics and social marketing in local markets to ensure that medical abortion drugs are available at pharmacies. MSZ will also strengthen its partnership with the government through the establishment of contracts to provide specific services on behalf of the government, to further develop a digital communication model to facilitate the concrete availability of safe abortion, and to cooperate with the Ministry of Health’s health clinics to provide youth-friendly SRHR services for young people. MSZ will also participate in advocacy work and conduct dialogue for political change in the area of access to safe abortion and for contraceptives and other reproductive health commodities. MSZ will engage in strategic partnerships for community engagement with local partners. The Sida-funded initiative is expected to ensure that 102,500 women and girls access SRHR services, 14,900 medical abortion pills are distributed and 16,000 safe abortions can be performed. The effort is estimated to prevent 455 maternal deaths, 48,000 unintended pregnancies and 27,700 unsafe abortions.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Marie Stopes Zambia har inkommit med en ansökan om stöd om 40 MSEK till att genomföra programmet Scaling Up Access to Comprehensive SRHR for Women and Girls in Zambia under perioden 2018-2021. Insatsen syftar till att förbättra tillgången och utnyttjandet av hälso- och sjukvårdstjänster inom ramen för sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa. MSZ arbetar brett med att bistå de zambiska hälsomyndigheterna med att erbjuda kvinnor och flickor moderna preventivmedel, information och utbildning om sex, samlevnad och reproduktiv hälsa samt med tillgång till mediciner, rådgivning och service kring säkra aborter. Ett tydligt fokus är på fattiga kvinnor, ungdomar och unga kvinnor både på landsbygden och i urbana områden och samt andra marginaliserade grupper som t ex funktionshindrade och hiv-smittade.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Marie Stopes Zambia has applied to Sida for funding of 40 Million SEK to carry out the Scaling Up Access to Comprehensive SRHR for Women and Girls in Zambia during the period 2018-2021. The contribution aims to increase equitable access and utilization of sexual and reproductive health services. MSZ works in close collaboration with local and central health authorities to provide modern family planning services, information and education about SRHR and with provision of drugs, counselling and access to safe abortion services. A clear focus is to provide quality services to young women and girls in both urban and rural settings, in particular poor women and girls and other disenfranchised and hard to reach populations such as disabled and hiv infected women and adolescents.

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The year 2019 is the second implementation year of the Sida-funded Marie Stopes programme and it has been a year with good results and positive progress, despite the financial crisis in Zambia resulting in increased costs for service provision, including fuel and transport. MSZ reached out to 59 949 women with contraceptive services across 20 districts and 357 sites in four provinces, against a target of 51 934. Out of the above number, 13 percent of the clients were adolescent clients between the ages of 10 and 19 and 28 percent young women between 20 and 24, hence 41 percent of all clients are below 25 years of age. In total MSZ managed to provide 69 308 services during the year. Key results for the year include: 1) 59 949 women were provided with family planning services through outreach services and static services at the MSZ clinic and youth centre of which 13 percent were teenagers. 2) 79 percent of the family planning services provided by MSZ were long-acting and permanent contraceptive methods, against "only" 21 percent of short-term methods, which are the most popular methods among Zambian women as a whole. 3) 25 percent of the women receiving long acting methods opted for the IUCD, the intra-uterine copper device, which is three times higher than in 2018 and hence a record high rate of this particular contraception. 73 percent of women preferred the implant, and 2 percent the tubal ligation. 4) 19 506 safe abortion services were delivered against a target of 12 000 and compared to 9 473 in 2018. 5) 35 health workers in the public health facilities were trained by MSZ in the National Comprehensive Abortion Care guidelines, in partnership with Ministry of Health, Ipas, CHAI and Zambian Medical Association. The results from the various service models provided by Marie Stopes in 2019 included the following: - Three outreach teams operate in Northern, Eastern and Copperbelt provinces and provide services in rural, hard to reach areas. The teams provided 58 414 FP services for women, adolescents and young women. In 2019, MSZ introduced a new model of service delivery splitting the outreach teams into smaller teams thereby enabling them to spread their services and reach more rural clients. The teams work within the public health facilities automatically transferring skills to health workers. A positive finding is that many rural women, that are traditionally seen to be preferring short term contraceptives, are moving over to long-term methods. This is particularly remarkable as 2019 saw a massive national (global) acute shortage of Jadelle, the most popular implant, and yet the increase in long-term choices was significant. - The two stationary clinics Marie Stopes family centre and the Diva youth centre located in Kabulonga, Lusaka, provided 7 504 services. The Family Centre recruited an obstetrician/gynecology specialist doctor, a pharmacist and expanded on its laboratory capacity. - The MS Ladies operating as community nurses in the high density urban and peri-urban slum areas of Lusaka, Ndola and Kitwe, provided 10 520 services, which is an increase with 54 percent from 2018. The community nurses work closely with the peri-urban highly congested public health facilities. Of the total family planning services provided, 83 percent were long term methods. - The strong focus on attracting youth has also shown positive results and innovative strategies as MSZ worked with the Ministry of Education to provide contraceptive services to tertiary learning institutions through the use of a mobile caravan. The mobile caravans are used to service adolescents in the urban and per-urban slums together with the MS Ladies and services 30 to 40 youth per day. In 2019, the caravan recorded an average of 562 adolescent clients per month compared to 136 compared to the static Diva centre. The stationary clinics are the only MSZ sites where safe abortion can be provided. In 2019, there were 321 abortions recorded and 103 cervical cancer testing and treatment services along with 703 lab tests and 397 hiv tests. Due to its positive results, the caravan model is being replicated also by UNICEF and MOH in other parts of urban settings. - MSZ partnered with Restless Development to expand on the number of staff working on the 5600 Toll-free contact centre and the caravan mobile outreach activities. In 2019, MSZ contact centre answered more than 18 000 calls of which 17 percent were adolescents, many of whom were referred to the nearest youth-friendly health service or safe abortion provider, including the MSZ clinic in Lusaka. About 12 percent of the calls were abortion-related. - Under the commercial sales, a total of 38 912 medical abortion drug units were distributed across pharmacies and private and public clinics in 9 provinces. It should be noted that MSZ captures the number of tablets that have been distributed or sold to pharmacies, and is unable to follow up if the tablets were in fact used. - MSZ conducted capacity-building for 12 public health providers in contraceptive service delivery, infection prevention, medical emergency management and values clarification and attitude training (VCAT) for abortion, to enhance quality of care. Another 15 providers were trained in providing the newly introduced self-injecting short term contraception, and 22 government providers were trained in comprehensive abortion care in Lusaka province. Following this training, six provinces have requested similar trainings to be conducted in 2020. MSZ works with the development of a standardized training curriculum for health providers in Zambia on provision of safe abortion together with Ipas, CHAI, Options and Zambian Medical Association. - MSZ started working more with disabled persons as a particularly marginalized group in Zambia with regards to service access. An internal disability policy was completed with a strong focus on young people as they are often double marginalized. The policy will guide the work of MSZ in the years to come. - Financially, MSZ underspent in 2019 with expenditures amounting to 73 percent of the planned allocation. There were however higher than planned expenditures under budget lines for fuel and transport. The loadshedding during the year was costly for MSZ that had to run generators to maintain the cold chain of vaccines and other supplies. In sum, the year has shown remarkable progress, despite financial crisis in Zambia with increased costs for fuel, transport and maintenance of utilities and services. MSZ has reached good results in increasing the number of women actively choosing a long-term contraceptive method which will reduce the number of unintended and unwanted pregnancies, unsafe abortions and risks related to multiple, frequent pregnancies and deliveries. The conscious ambition to reach out to adolescents is bearing fruit with the use of mobile caravans in the peri-urban slums for the poor and marginalized youth and in the universities for the sexually active at-risk young women. In the slums of Lusaka and Copperbelt, the caravan model attracts 30 to 40 adolescent clients per day compared to the Diva centre that serves 10 per day. In total (going beyond the Sida programme), 15 percent of clients in the peri-urban areas are adolescents and 32 percent are young women between 20 and 24, hence almost half of all clients are below 25. Looking at the overall number of MSZ clients across all services provided in both rural and urban settings, 13 percent being adolescents is still however too modest. The high number of adolescents reached in the urban areas is countered by a low number of youth being reached in the rural areas. The imbalance can be explained by the fact that MSZ has scaled up their outreach into the rural areas giving higher total numbers of rural women reached, but with limited reach to younger rural girls. As the Sida programme has a strong focus on outreach in rural areas, data from the programme shows that out of all the adolescents reached in the programme with contraceptive services, 77,5 percent are in fact rural youth, clearly showing that Sida's support to MSZ manages to reach these adolescents, albeit in limited real numbers.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen syftar till att bidra till övergångsprocessen genom att genomföra demokratistärkande åtgärder som främjar reformen av det colombianska valsystemet genom att; 1) Stärka samhällsorganisationer och lokala institutioner under övergångsprocessen genom åtgärder som syftar till att stärka informationsprocesser och initiativtagande hos medborgare; 2) Stärka lokala institutioner genom bättre förståelse av korruption associerat till det colombianska valsystemet; 3) Påverka reformprocesser som syftar till att stärka demokratin. Programmet får 11197 645 SEK mellan åren 2017-2021.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The intervention aims to contribute to the transition process towards the democratic strengthening through actions that promote the modernization of the Colombian electoral system by 1) Strengthening social organizations and local institutions during the transition process, through actions aimed to reinforce information processes, formation, and citizen action. 2) Strengthening local institutions through a better comprehension of corruption phenomena associated to the political-electoral system. 3) Influence reform processes of political and electoral matter, aiming for the strengthening of democracy. The program will receive 11 197 645 SEK between 2017-2021.

The Electoral Observation Mission (MOE) will have contributed to a transition for democratic strengthening by carrying out actions that promote the modernization of the Colombian electoral system and the broadening of local and daily democracy.

tag.narrative: 16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.5 - Substantially reduce corruption and bribery in all their forms.
16.5 - Väsentligt minska alla former av korruption och mutor.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.

4.7 - By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and non-violence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture’s contribution to sustainable development.

4.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla studerande får de kunskaper och färdigheter som behövs för att främja en hållbar utveckling, bland annat genom utbildning för hållbar utveckling och hållbara livsstilar, mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet, främjande av en kultur av fred, icke-våld och globalt medborgarskap samt värdesättande av kulturell mångfald och kulturens bidrag till hållbar utveckling.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

description.narrative: The Sida-funded contribution with MOE 2017-2020 is based on 3 specific thematic objetives: 1) Transition and Democratic strengthening, 2) Corruption, politics and democracy, and 3) Advocacy among Society and State institutions. Apart from NPO Buenaventura's summary of results achieved by MOE during 2019 (see UM2017/23132/BOGO-60), MOE continues to deliver high-impact results in 2020 despite the COVID-19 challenges. Although reporting for 2020 is not to be submitted until March 2021, it is possible to give an preliminary assessment of the results achieved during the reporting year so far. Some early achievements reported by MOE during 2020 include the following: - A noteworthy impact on the new Electoral Code (código electoral) and political reform. - Three investigations on corruption during COVID-19 public hiring processes. - Pre-electoral support to Community Action Boards (Juntas de Acción Comunal). - With regards to special/vulnerable groups: An intervention before the Constitutional Court on Raizal voting rights, an assessment on how to implement on special measures persons with disabilities, and a training module for democratic participation of youths in collaboration with the National Electoral Council (CNE), the Registrator General's Office and ESAP. - Follow-up on the status of bills regarding parity and equal representation of women in Congress, as well as bills related to political violence against women. - Guidelines for a protocol to prevent political violence against women. - Monitoring of political violence against women, through media analysis and participation in forums and events. - Gender streamlining in all of MOE's research projects. - Electoral observation for 7 atypical elections (Sutatausa, Valle de San Juan, Achí, San Zenón, Providencia, Repelón and Barrancominas), as well as an observation kit for these elections and a biosafety protocol for elections. - Developed the methodology for an Electoral Corruption Risk Index. - Supported measures for electronic participation in civilian participatory elections (such as guild, unions, school, and university elections). - Electoral risk mapping for two localities in Bogotá (with IDPAC), a historical analysis on political violence for the Truth Commission and risk mapping for capitals across the country (with UNDP). For more in-depth information regarding these activities, see UM2017/23132/BOGO-84. However, in addition to the information highlighted above, it is important to focus on two other key accomplishments during 2020. Protocol for Voting Rights for Trans Persons (December 2020) During 2020, MOE, in collaboration with the Grupo de Acción y Apoyo a Personas Trans (GAAT), and Caribe Afirmativo, drafted a proposal for a protocol to guarantee the voting rights for trans persons. This protocol, financed on MOE's end by Sida's contribution, was shared with the international community in July for comments, and then formally presented to the National Electoral Council (CNE) in September. In a historical effort to guarantee voting rights for all free from discrimination, the CNE adopted the proposal verbatim. On December 1, 2020, Sweden was invited to the official adoption ceremony of the Protocol, now a formal CNE resolution (Res. 3480 del 13 de noviembre de 2020). The CNE has vowed to work with with other electoral bodies, including the National Registrator's Office to make sure the protocol is thoroughly implemented henceforth. During the adoption ceremony, in which Ambassador Helena Storm offered some words, the proponents of the iniciative announced their intention to work on a Latin American-level protocol for voting rights of trans persons in collaboration with other regional democracy NGOs. The Colombia Embassy reported the protocol to EUROLATIN as part of Sida Colombia's efforts in the drive for democracy, and was notified that this accomplishment will be featured on Sida's 2020 annual open and official report. A compendium of this process can be found from UM2017/23132/BOGO-76 to BOGO-82, and BOGO-87. Political Violence Report: A Country Without Leaders is not a Country (September 2020) In September 2020, MOE launched a political violence report against social leaders in 2020. The report, financed by Sida and in collaboration with the European Union, obtained significant media notoriety in Colombia and was also picked up by international outlets like Reuters. Although political violence reports are not new to MOE, this report marked a change in the presentation strategy. MOE is determined to raise greater awareness on the situation of social leaders in Colombia internationally. As such, it will begin presenting these reports in English, so that they can be easily shared among international audiences. The Embassy shared the English media kit created by MOE with the Communications office at Sida HQ, who in turn shared this information with the Colombia desks of the Swedish radio and TV. However, in this occasion the news failed to be mentioned by Swedish media (for more information on the Embassy's outreach effort for this report see UM2017/23132/BOGO-88). It is likely that MOE will reach out to the Embassy again for support in broadcasting the results of these political violence reports in the future.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Connect Rural Uganda - leaving noone behind in the Digital era - UNCDF
COVID-19 Connect Rural Uganda - leaving noone behind in the Digital era - UNCDF

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Precis som tidigare våg av teknologisk utveckling (exempelvis tillgång till energi och elektricitet) förändrar digital utveckling förutsättningar för den globala ekonomin och för människors sätt att leva och arbeta. Världen över talar man om en fjärde industriell revolution. Digital teknologi har potential att stimulera tillväxt och produktivitet samt att stödja inkluderande ekonomisk utveckling. Den kan öka produktivitet av kapital och arbetskraft och möjliggöra deltagande i globala värdekedjor för konsumenter, företag och regeringar. Den digitala ekonomin kan också bidra till ökad inkludering bland annat genom att minska transaktionskostnader, öka jämlik tillgång till information, globala nätverk och skal-ekonomi. På många platser i världen kan man se att den digitala ekonomin har möjliggjort inkludering av tidigare marginaliserade och exkluderade grupper. Men alla har inte kunnat dra nytta av digitaliseringens fördelar. Möjligheterna är ojämnt fördelade mellan samhällsgrupper, kön, sektorer och länder och många riskerar fortfarande att lämnas efter i utvecklingen. Några orsaker till ojämlikhet och så kallade "digitala klyftor" är brist på tillgång till teknik exempelvis på grund av prissättning (affordability), men även på grund av låg utbildningsnivå i allmänhet inklusive brist på kunskap om existerande teknologi. Könsbaserade digitala klyftor blir extra tydliga när man väger in hur prissättningen påverkar olika målgrupper, men även kopplat till faktorer som okunskap om digitalisering, vilket i sig ofta är en effekt av utbildningsnivå, sysselsättning samt inkomstnivå. Restriktiva och patriarkala normer och sedvänjor bidrar också till att individer inte kan dra fördel av den teknologi som finns. Även här tenderar kvinnor och flickor att hamna på efterkälken. Med digitaliseringens omfattande påverkan på ekonomin i stort, finns skäl att säkerställa att Uganda inte hamnar efter i utvecklingen och att redan stor ojämlikhet mellan exempelvis kön, etniska grupper (inkluderat olika flykinggrupper) eller olika regioner förstärks (ojämlikhet som grundorsak till fattigdom utvecklas även i ambassadens multidimensionella fattigdomsanalys, 2017).
Den föreslagna insatsen, Connect Rural Uganda, är ett femårigt program mellan åren 2019-2024 (halvår 2019-halvår 2024) med syfte att stärka ekonomisk egenmakt och inkludering hos målgrupper på den Ugandiska landsbygden med särskilt fokus på flyktingar, kvinnor och flickor, ungdomar (15-30 år) samt små-jordbrukare . Målgrupperna överlappar naturligtvis. För marknadsutveckling är också små- och medelstora företag en viktig målgrupp. Centralt för programmet är att man söker nå några av de allra mest utsatta målgrupperna. Därför fokuserar man på flyktingar och värdsamhällen i Norra Uganda där en stor andel är multidimensionellt fattiga (och kvinnor och ungdomar särskilt utsatta), där rättigheter inte tillgodoses och där tillgången till service är satt under stor press med anledning av det stora antalet flyktingar under senare år. Trots Ugandas progressiva flyktingpolicy är det osannolikt att flyktingarna kan återvända till sina hemländer på kort eller medellång sikt. Insatser som fokuserar på flyktingars integrering i Uganda är därför av stor vikt.
I programmet prioriteras digitala lösningar som kan förstärka utvecklingseffekter inom sektorerna jordbruk, hälsa och utbildning. Exempel på resultat som programmet kan förväntas bidra till är att lantbrukare har förbättrat sin tillgång till information om jordbruksmetoder, marknader och teknologi, digital finansiell service samt tillgång till energi för ändamål inom lantbruk. Att jordbruksföretag har förbättrat distributionen av sina produkter och marknadsföringssystem samt fått bättre tillgång till lån. Att skolor har effektiviserat betalnings- samt uppföljningssystem samt att målgrupperna därmed fått tillgång till ökad kvalitet i utbildning och utbildningsmaterial. Att befolkning på landsbygden har förbättrade möjligheter att göra betalningar för hälsoservice genom tillgång till finansiering (sparande/lån/försäkring). Samt att nya affärsmodeller och teknologier för att leverera service till befolkning på landsbygden har skalats upp.
Insatsens primära geografiska fokus är på flyktingar och värdsamhällen i Norra Uganda i distrikten Lira, Oyam, Dokolo, Alebtong, Masindi, Apac, Yumbe, Moyo, Arua, Adjumani, Nebbi, Zombo och Maracha. Det geografiska fokuset har valts utifrån regionens höga fattigdomsnivå, befolkningens sårbarhet samt frånvaron av tillgång till samhällsservice och inkluderande ekonomisk tillväxt. Men också utifrån de möjligheter som finns för introducering och ökad användning av digitala lösningar för att förstärka utvecklingseffekter för dessa sårbara grupper. Mobiltelefoni erbjuder särskilda möjligheter i detta avseende. Tillgången till mobiltelefoni har ökat dramatiskt i Uganda. 53% av kvinnorna och 71% av männen äger en mobiltelefon (2016/2017). Flyktingar tenderar att i större utsträckning än befolkningen i övrigt ha tillgång till en mobiltelefon med anledning av behov att kommunicera med familjemedlemmar i hemlandet samt genomförande av exempelvis finansiella transaktioner så som remitteringar. Finansiell inkludering (ex. mobila transaktioner) utgör ofta den största drivkraften för människor att skaffa sig en mobiltelefon.
Digital teknologi har inte bara revolutionerat hur finansiell service i stor skala kan bedrivas, till priser som gör tjänsterna tillgängliga för en fattigare (”un-banked”) del av befolkningen. Utvecklingen har också kommit att betyda mycket för hur annan typ av service i andra sektorer av ekonomin (ex. hälsa och utbildning) kan tillgängliggöras, med stora möjligheter att förändra livet för fattiga människor och stödja framväxten av hållbara affärsmodeller i för ekonomin viktiga sektorer (ex. jordbruk). Finansiell inkludering genom digital teknologi blir på så vis allt mer integrerat i icke- finansiella lösningar och kan utgöra en nyckel för att förstärka värdet och effekterna av denna service för fattiga människor. Här kan UNCDFs mandat och ingång via finansiell inkludering, samt mobilisering av marknadsaktörer spela en betydande roll för utvecklingseffekter på marken.
Så som insatsen är strukturerad bedöms den kunna nå de fattigaste och ha direkt påverkan på fattigas livssituation; men den bedöms också kunna bidra till mer indirekta och långsiktiga effekter för fattigdomsminskning. UNCDF använder sig av Human-Centric-Design i sin insatsdesign. På så sätt säkras att digitala lösningar och marknadsaktörers service (inom jordbruk, hälsa och utbildning) utgår från den fattiga människans perspektiv och behov. Dessa lösningar skapar förutsättningar för de allra fattigaste att inkluderas i samhällsekonomin och nås av kvalitativ service som de har rätt till. Genom UNCDFs samarbete med marknadsaktörer (både mobilisering av aktörer och kapital) skapas dock också möjligheter för marknadsutveckling på medellång-lång sikt som inkluderar stärkande av företags affärsmodeller, riskreducering som kan leda till fler företagsetableringar, förbättrad service och bättre priser till gagn för fattiga människor och ekonomisk och social inkludering. Exempel på samarbetspartners kan vara mobiltelefonoperatörer, teknologiföretag (ex. inom jordbruk, utbildning, hälsa och finans), olika sammanslutningar på lokal nivå (ex. SACCOs), skolor, vårdinrättningar m.fl.
Implementering av programmet utgår från fyra principer: 1) Marknadssystemansats för att öka digital service i Uganda 2) Implementering genom partners (i huvudsak) genom privatsektor, lokal och nationell regering 3) Utgå från, samt bygga på redan befintliga digitala lösningar, kanaler och strukturer. 4) Söka vägar för stöd genom inkubation av företag samt investeringar.
Programmets aktiviteter är kategoriserade i fyra delprogram/workstreams (WS) som vart och ett bidrar till den övergripande målsättningen. Det första delprogrammet fokuserar på att skapa förutsättningar för policy och reglering med målsättningen att den ugandiska regeringen implementerar policy som ökar tillgången till, och användandet av, digital service. Delprogram två fokuserar på ekosystem för digitala betalningar, med målsättning att medborgare ska ha förbättrat sin tillgång till och ökat sin användning av digitala betalningslösningar. Delprogram tre fokuserar på inkluderande innovationer, med målsättningen att skala upp nya affärsmodeller och teknologi för tillhandahållande av service till människor på landsbygden. Delprogram fyra ska stärka kundens egenmakt, med målsättning att medborgarna ska ha den kunskap och de beteenden som behövs för att kunna använda digital teknologi. I tillägg till dessa fyra delprogram, stödjer UNCDF forskning (egna studier/analyser eller genom uppdrag till andra aktörer) samt investerar i lärande och delning av kunskap. Detta bidrar till att skapa ett tillåtande digitalt ekosystem.
Programmet utgår från den så kallade MSD-ansatsen (Market systems development approach/ Making markets work for the poor) och fokuserar på långsiktigt ägarskap, systemförändringar, ”uppskalning” av nya och befintliga lösningar samt möjliga reformer på valda marknader (jordbruk, hälsa och utbildning). Samverkan med privat sektor kommer att sökas där den bedöms kunna bidra till måluppfyllelse och där insatsens målsättningar sammanfaller med företages kärnverksamhet samt socialt- och miljömässigt ansvarstagande. UNCDF (och även ansatsen generellt) framhåller särskilt vikten av att facilitera för marknadsaktörer, men betonar att UNCDF står utanför marknadssystemet med rollen att stödja förändringar på ett sätt som gör att marknaden kan fungera bättre. UNCDF slår fast att tid, koordinering och partnerskap med en bredd av aktörer, risk-minimerande instrument, en iterativ metodologi, en ansats som bygger på "learning by doing" samt korsbefruktning mellan olika värdekedjor är nödvändigt för att nå resultat. UNCDFs strategi är därför att vara katalytisk och att stötta framväxten av hållbara affärsmodeller i samverkan med marknadens aktörer. UNCDF betonar också vikten av att i relevanta fall ha en mäklande roll av såväl kunskap och marknadsinformation som mellan olika typer av aktörer (exempelvis humanitära och utvecklingsaktörer eller privata och offentliga aktörer). Programmet har goda förutsättningar att bidra till ett närmande mellan humanitär verksamhet och långsiktigt utvecklingssamarbete.
UNCDFs globala strategiska ramverk samt bidrag till utvecklingsmålen: Connect Rural Uganda utgör en del av UNCDF's globala strategiska ramverk "Inklusiva Digitala Ekonomier" och kompletterar och bygger på tidigare och existerande program av UNCDF i Uganda. Programmet ligger i linje med UNCDFs vision "Ett klimat för inkluderande digital utveckling där alla kan nå framgång" (översättning från ansökan). Programmets bidrag till de hållbara utvecklingsmålen, utifrån ett målgruppsperspektiv är i första hand: fokus på kvinnor (SDG 5 jämställdhet), flyktingar (SDG 10: reduced inequalities, och ungdomar och små och medelstora företag (SDG8: anständiga arbetsvillkor och eknomiskt tillväxt). Ytterligare kommer digital service i sektorer att bidra till målsättningar inom: lantbruk (SDG2: noll hunger), hälsa (SDG3: god hälsa och välmående), utbildning (SDG4: utbildning av god kvalitet), energi (SDG7: energi till överkompligt pris och miljö/klimat (SDG13: handling för klimatet) samt finansiering av målen (financing for development/Addis Abeba Agenda för Action).

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Just like with previous waves of technological innovation, such as the development of electrification, digital technologies are remaking economies and societies. There is an ongoing "fourth industrial revolution". The digital economy fosters growth and productivity and supports inclusive development. Adoption and usage of digital technologies raises the productivity of capital and labour and enables the participation in global value chains. It raises productivity of capital and labour and enables participation in global value chains. The digital economy contributes to great inclusion by lowering transaction costs, addressing information asymmetries and exploiting economies of scale and network effects. Through these mechanisms, the digital economy has increased the accessibility to previously marginalised groups of a whole range of markets and services.
As much as the digital transformation offers immense opportunities for economies and societies, the benefits of the digital transformation are currently not equally balanced between societal groups, genders sectors and countries and many still risk being left behind development. There are a number of root causes of the digital divide, including hurdles to access, affordability, education (or lack thereof) and lack of technological literacy, as well as inherent biases and socio-cultural norms that lead to digital exclusion. Affordability is a challenge for all, but affects disproportionally more women and girls, and remains one of the key hurdles in accessing ICTs. The digital gender divide is fuelled by digital illiteracy, which is often a cause of education, employment status and income level. With the large impact that the digital development has on the economy at large, there is reason to ensure that Uganda does not lag behind the development and that already large inequalities are not exacerbated, be it along geographical lines or with gender, ethnic or other dimensions (inequality as a root-cause and driver of poverty is further developed in EoS multidimensional poverty analysis, 2017).
The proposed contribution is called Connect Rural Uganda and is a five-year program, 2019-2024 (mid-2019 to mid- 2024) aiming to, through increased digitalization, empower rural communities with particular focus on refugees, women and girls, youths and smallholder farmers/agri-businesses. The target groups are of course overlapping. For market development small and medium sized enterprises is an important target group. The programme aims to reach vulnerable populations wherefor refugees and host communities in Northern Uganda are in focus; a region where a large majority is multidimesionally poor (and women and youth extremely vulnerable), where rights are being violated and where access to quality service is strained from the large influx of refugees in recent years. Despite the Ugandan Governments progressive refugee policy it is unlikely that the refugees will return to their countries of origin in the short /medium term. Therefore, programming of interventions must consider practical solutions towards integration within Uganda.
The scoping of the program and the focus on the three sectors agriculture, education and health, builds on an analysis of current contextual challenges to rural development and assessment of key sector areas to which digital innovations and technology can be leveraged to unlock sustainable change in livelihoods in refugee areas. Examples of specified outcomes for the program are for example that farmers have improved access to information on agricultural management practices, markets and farming technologies, digital financial services, and power for farming practices. That agro-MSMEs have improved commodity distribution and marketing systems, and better access to credit. That schools have improved efficiencies in payment and monitoring systems, and access to quality teaching and learning materials. That rural populations have improved options for health payments and financing (savings, loans, insurance). And that new business models and technologies for delivering services are scaled for rural communities.
The intervention targets refugees and host communities in Northern Uganda in the districts of Lira, Oyam, Dokolo, Alebtong, Masindi, Apac, Yumbe, Moyo, Arua, Adjumani, Nebbi, Zombo, Maracha. The geographic focus has been chosen with regards to its poverty levels (one of the poorest regions in Uganda), high vulnerability, lack of access to social services (e.g. health and education) and lack of inclusive economic development. But also with regards to the opportunities and market potential when it comes to introducing and scaling digital solutions to leverage development impact. Mobile technology offers important opportunities in this regard. Access to mobile technology has increased with drastic speed in Uganda. 53% of females and 71% of men owns a mobile phone (2016). Refugees tend to, more than the population at large, access mobile technology with the specific needs to communicate with family members in their home country or use it for financial transactions like remittances. Financial inclusion (including mobile transations) is many times a driver for people to secure access to a phone.
Digital technologies have not only revolutionized how financial services can be provided at scale at very low cost for the un-banked, but are also connecting those financial services to "real-economy"- related services / solutions that can transform the lives of the poor, or support the M-SME-growth. The expansion of financial inclusion through digital technology is becoming integrated with other non-financial services that have the potential to greatly enhance the value, usage and impact of those services for the poor. With its role and mandate and with its entry point through financial inclusion and tools to mobilise market actors, UNCDF can play an important role in leveraging development impact on the ground.
It is assessed that the intervention can contribute to direct poverty reduction that will change the lives of the poorest, but also to contribute to more structural and long term impact on poverty reduction. In design and imlementation UNCDF uses a human centric design approach. This will secure that digital solutions and service (within agriculture, health and education) departs from poor peoples perspectives and needs. These solutions will therefore facilitate for the poorest (identified target groups) to access qualitative services that they have the right to, as well as for inclusion of poor people in their society and economy. Through UNCDFs collaboration with market players, conditions will also be created for a more inclusive market development in the medium- to longterm. This can be seen as for example development of business models and crowding in of private sector which impacts access to service and better prices to the benefit of poor people and their social and economic inclusion in society. Potential partners are mobile operators, technology companeis (e.g. agriculture, education or health), various community based organisations (e.g. SACCOs), schools, health clinics etc.
The programme implementation will follow four key principles: 1) Market system approach to increase digital services in Uganda, 2) Implementation through partners from the private sector, local and national government 3) Leveraging existing and working digital solutions and channels and structures 4) Dedicated pathways for incubation and investments
The programme activities are categorized in four workstreams, which each contribute to the overall objective. The workstreams focus on Enabling policy and regulation with the objective that the Government of Uganda implements policies that enable access and usage of digital services; Open digital payment ecosystem, with the objective that the Rural community members have improved access to and increasingly use digital payment accounts; Inclusive innovation, with the objective that new business models, and technologies for delivering services, are scaled for rural communities. And finally Customer empowerment, with the objective that the Rural community members have the knowledge, skills, and behaviors needed to access and use digital services. In addition to these four work streams, UNCDF conducts research, and invests in learning and knowledge sharing, which contributes to an enabling digital ecosystem.
The programme takes "Making markets work for the poor (M4) approach" as a starting point. The market centric approach is expected to safeguard that specific interventions are designed and implemented to have systemic impact (and therefore sustainability) and to contribute to market reforms within the sectors of agriculture, health and education. Partnerships with the private sector will be formed where expected development results overlap with a company's core business objective, and where companies are committed to social and environmental responsibility in their operations. The intervention will trigger pro-poor market development impact that would not have emerged without the facilitation and coordination of UNCDF for piloting and/or scaling up pro-poor designed digital solutions. Facilitation of partnerships means that UNCDF recognizes the fact that they are external players, standing outside the market system, whose role is to stimulate and support changes in the way the market works. UNCDF also recognizes that time, collaborative effort among multiple partners, de-risking instruments, an iterative methodology, a learning by doing approach and cross-fertilisation across different value chains will be of importance to achive programme results. UNCDF’s main strategy is therefore to be catalytic and apply the mindset of developing a viable business case with the private sector actors. The role of UNCDF is not only to provide risk capital grants and technical assistance but also to broker knowledge and market information about the hard-to-reach consumer segments as well as broker and promote partnerships between different sets of actors (e.g. humanitarian/development actors and/or private/public actors). The program has potential to cross fertilize results in the nexus between humanitarian work and development cooperation and beteween public and private actors.
UNCDFs global strategic framework and contribution to Agenda 2030: The Connect Rural Uganda is part of UNCDF's global strategic framework “Inclusive Digital Economy” and complements and builds on previous and existing UNCDF programs in Uganda. The program falls under UNCDF’s vision “An inclusive digital environment where everyone can thrive”. In terms of impact on various SDGs, from a customer segment perspective, the Uganda program has a specific focus on women (SDG 5: gender equality), refugees (SDG 10: reduced inequalities) and youths & MSMEs (SDG8: Decent work and economic growth). Furthermore, it will explore digital services in various sectors: agriculture (SDG2: zero hunger), health (SDG3: Good health and well-being), Education (SDG4: Quality Education), Energy (SDG7: affordable and clean energy & SDGs 13: climate action) and finance.

The overall objective of the intervention is to “empower rural communities- smallholder farmers, agribusiness and refugees- in Uganda to lead productive and healthy lives by expanding access and usage to digital services". The low income rural population has not benefitted equally from technological developments, such as phones and information services, agriculture equipment, digital finance and other ICT solutions. Production innovations that have boosted agriculture in developing countries over the past 40 years have not benefited the rural poorest. The same applies to access to modern, basic services such as energy, health, and education. The rate at which digital technology is allowing societies to grow at a faster pace, brings worry about the impact of the digital divide and the exclusion for those who do not have opportunity or choice to participate in digital economies. Identifying, adapting and enabling access to digital innovation and technology solutions for the low income vulnerable communities holds potential to impact their livelihoods and facilitate sustained escapes out of poverty. The programme activities are categorized in four workstreams, which each contribute to the overall objective. Workstream one focus on Enabling policy and regulation with the objective that the Government of Uganda implements policies that enable access and usage of digital services. Workstream two focus on Open digital payment ecosystem, with the objective that the Rural community members have improved access to and increasingly use digital payment accounts. Workstream three focuses on Inclusive innovation, with the objective that New business models and technologies for delivering services are scaled for rural communities. And finally workstream four focuses on Customer empowerment, with the objective that the Rural community members have the knowledge, skills, and behaviors needed to access and use digital services In addition to these four work streams, UNCDF conducts research, and invests in learning and knowledge sharing, which contributes to an enabling digital ecosystem. The theory of Change and Results framework specifies outcomes on sector level, Client/beneficiary level and stakeholder level (see Theory of change in programme document). Examples of specified outcomes for the programme are: - Farmers have improved access to information on agricultural management practices, markets and farming technologies, digital financial services, and power for farming practices. - Agro MSMEs have improved commodity distribution and marketing systems, and better access to credit. - Schools have improved efficiencies in payment and monitoring systems, and access to quality teaching and learning materials. - Rural populations have improved options for health payments and financing (savings, loans, insurance). - Community Health Extension Workers have increased capacity and knowledge, and more efficient communication with their community. - Health officials have access to improved monitoring systems and improved decision making through access to data - Market players make digital payment services available, accessible, affordable, reliable and appropriate for customer needs - New business models and technologies for delivering services are scaled for rural communities - New business models and delivery channels for building financial and digital capabilities, and soft and hard skills of customers, are piloted and deployed at scale In terms of impact on various SDGs, from a customer segment perspective, the Uganda program has a specific focus on women (SDG 5: gender equality), refugees (SDG 10: reduced inequalities) and youths & MSMEs (SDG8: Decent work and economic growth). Furthermore, it will explore digital services in various sectors: agriculture (SDG2: zero hunger), health (SDG3: Good health and well-being), Education (SDG4: Quality Education), Energy (SDG7: affordable and clean energy & SDGs 13: climate action) and finance.
