title.narrative: UNFPA - UN Women Gemensamt program för att förebygga könsrelaterat våld i Uganda
UNFPA - UN Women Joint Programme on Gender Based Violence in Uganda 2018-2023

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 FN’s befolkningsfond (UNFPA) och UN Women har tillsammans lämnat in en ansökan till Sida för att genomföra ett gemensamt program för att förebygga könsrelaterat våld (Gender Based Violence - GBV) i Uganda under en femårs period, 2018-2023. Den totala finansieringen för programmet uppgår till 28 750 000 USD. Titeln på programmet är “Gender Based Violence Prevention and Response with integration of Sexual Reproductive Health and Rights in hard to reach (furthest behind) and vulnerable populations in Uganda” och det gemensamma programmet syftar till att bidra till eliminering av GBV och förbättrad Sexuell och Reproduktiv Hälsa och Rättigheter (SRHR) för kvinnor, män, flickor och pojkar, inklusive eftersatta och sårbara befolkningar i Uganda. Målen är 1) Policys, lagstiftning och ansvarsutkrävande med fokus på GBV och SRHR omsätts till handling, 2) Minskad social tolerans för GBV och förbättrad SRHR, 3) Ökat utnyttjande av integrerade GBV- och SRHR-tjänster i distrikten och 4) Förstärkt samordning, partnerskap, lärande och innovation för integrerad SRHR och sektorövergripande GBV-respons och prevention.
Programmet kommer implementeras i 14 distrikt i Uganda varav två är flyktingmottagande distrikt. UNFPA och UN Women kommer genomföra programmet genom implementerande partners både på nationell och subnationell nivå (distrikt och kommuner). Programmet kommer implementeras utifrån tre gemensamma program-principer:
1. Främjande av lokalt ägarskap, ledarskap och ansvar för GBV- och SRHR-agendan 2. Mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och empowerment av kvinnor och flickor kommer informera alla aktiviteter inom ramen för detta program 3. En koordinerad och integrerad multisektoriell approach som inkluderar regeringen, civila samhället, kulturinstitutioner och den privata sektorn och stärker den nationella kapaciteten för att motverka GBV och förbättra SRHR
Båda FN-organisationerna arbetar med implementerande partners; statliga institutioner, civila samhället, trosbaserade organisationer, kultur- och religionsledare, forskningsinstitutioner, privatsektorn, medier och sociala ”influencers”.
Programmet har utvecklats utifrån Ugandas regerings prioriteringar samt genom en omfattande samrådsprocess med civila samhället, målgrupper, privatsektorn, och implementerande partners på nationell och subnationell nivå. Programmet är anpassat till den nationella utvecklingsplanen och FN:s gemensamma landplan (UNDAF); och är utformad för att bidra till genomförandet av relevanta nationella strategier för att eliminera GBV och främja SRHR, t.ex.: sektorplanen för social utveckling (SDSP), den nationella GBV-policyn, planen för rättvise-sektorn (JLOS SDP), de globala målen för hållbar utveckling (SDGs), planen för reproduktiv, mödra, barn och ungdomshälsa (RMNCAH Sharpened plan) och den nationella strategin för att minska barnäktenskap och tonårsgraviditeter. Genom dessa planer kommer regeringen att fördela resurser för att upprätthålla effekter och realisera jämställdhet och SRHR-resultat.
Insatsen syftar till att förbättra nationella indikatorer relaterade till GBV och SRHR. Det övergripande målet förväntas bidra till att minska alla former av könsrelaterat våld med 10%, minska proportionen av tonårsgraviditeter från 25% till 20%, sänka hiv-prevalensen från 6% till 5%, minska mödradödligheten från 336/100 000 till 325/100 000 och minska det icke-tillgodosedda behovet av preventivmedel (unmet need for contraceptives) från 28% till 15%
UNFPA kommer att vara Sveriges, representerat av Sida, avtalspart för det gemensamma programmet. En standardmall som tagits fram av FN:s utvecklingsgrupp (UNDG), Standard Administrative Arrangement (SAA) Joint programmes (Pass-Through Fund Management), vilken har fastställts av Sida som avtalsmall (beslut 2015-003649), kommer att användas för att reglera Sveriges bidrag till det FN-gemensamma programmet. SAA undertecknas av Sverige, representerat av Sida, och av UNFPA som administrativ agent (Administrative Agent (AA)). I rollen som AA administrerar UNFPA de medel som tillställs programmet och ansvarar för att sammanställa den finansiella rapporteringen från de deltagande FN-organen (Participating UN Organizations). UNFPA är också s.k. Convening Agent (sammankallande), vilket innebär att UNFPA har ansvar för den övergripande programkoordineringen och uppföljningen, samt att koordinera den narrativa rapporteringen. Både UNFPA och UN Women är deltagande FN-organ inom programmet (Participating UN Organizations), vilket innebär att de kommer att genomföra programverksamheten i enlighet med sina egna tillämpliga regler, policyer och förfaranden, inklusive upphandling samt urval och bedömning av genomförande partners.
UNFPA, som AA, kommer att utbetala medel från Sida till de deltagande FN-organen (UNFPA och UN Women) i enlighet med beslut från styrkommittén, programdokument och budgetar. Bägge organisationerna kommer därefter att vidarebefordra medel till sina respektive implementerande partners.
Till SAA biläggs för information en kopia av den överenskommelse (MoU) som upprättats specifikt för programmet mellan de deltagande FN-organen, Administrative Agent och Convening Agent, dvs. UNFPA och UN Women, där deras inbördes ansvar anges. De båda organen har i MoU kommit överens om inrättandet av en styrkommitté, för att underlätta ett effektivt samarbete mellan FN-organen och värdregeringen (Uganda) för genomförandet av det gemensamma programmet. Styrkommittén kommer överse programmet, ge strategisk vägledning och kommer att vara det övergripande beslutsorganet i vilket beslut om aktiviteter, budget och vidareförmedling av medel till respektive organisation kommer att hanteras. Representanter från regeringen, civila samhället, målgruppen och chefer för deltagande FN-organ deltar i styrkommittén. Sveriges ambassad i Uganda kommer att ha en observatörsroll. Årliga finansiella ställningstaganden och rapporter ska utarbetas av UNFPA och presenteras för och godkännas av styrkommittén.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) and United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women (UN Women) have jointly submitted an application to Sida for funding of 28 750 000 USD to carry out the Joint Programme on Gender Based Violence in Uganda during the 5-year period 2018-2023. With the title “Gender Based Violence Prevention and Response with integration of Sexual Reproductive Health and Rights in hard to reach (furthest behind) and vulnerable populations in Uganda”, the programme aims at contributing to the elimination of GBV and improvement of SRHR of women, men, girls and boys, including disadvantaged and vulnerable populations in Uganda. The objectives are 1) An enabling policy, legislative and accountability environment for elimination of GBV and improvement of SRHR is translated into action, 2) Reduced social tolerance for GBV and improved SRHR, 3) Increased utilization of quality integrated GBV and SRHR services in the target districts and 4) Strengthened coordination, partnership, learning and innovation for integrated SRHR and GBV multi-sectoral response and prevention.
The programme will be implemented in 14 districts in Uganda, of which two are refugee hosting districts. UNFPA and UN Women will implement the programme through their implementing partners at both national and subnational levels. The programme will be implemented according to three Joint Programme principles:
1. Promote local ownership, leadership and accountability for the GBV and SRHR agenda 2. Human rights, gender equality and empowerment of women and girls are the key foundation issues which inform all interventions for prevention and response to GBV under this programme 3. Coordinated and integrated multi-sectoral approach working with government, CSO’s, FBO’s, cultural institutions and the private sector to contribute towards strengthening national capacity.
Both UN organizations work with implementing partners; Government institutions, Civil Society Organizations (CSO’s), Faith Based Organizations (FBO’s), cultural and religious leaders, academia and research Institutions, private sector, media and social influencers.
The programme has been developed with the leadership of government and through an extensive consultative process with CSO’s, LGs, private sector, communities and IP’s at national and sub-national level. This programme is aligned with the National Development Plan and UNDAF and is designed to contribute to the implementation of: the Social Development Sector Plan (SDSP), the National GBV Policy, the 4th Justice Law and Order Sector (JLOS) Sector Development Plan (SDP), the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the Reproductive, Maternal, New born, Child & Adolescent Health (RMNCAH) sharpened plan, the National Strategy to End Child Marriage and Teenage pregnancy - government strategies to eliminate GBV and promote SRHR. Through these, Government will continue to allocate resources for sustaining impacts through this joint programme aiming at realisation of gender equality and SRHR outcomes.
The intervention is aiming at improving national indicators related to GBV and SRHR. Overall, it aims at a reduction of all forms of gender based violence with 10%, reducing teenage pregnancies from 25% to 20%, reducing HIV prevalence from 6% to 5%, improving maternal mortality rates from 336/100 000 to 325/100 000 and reducing the unmet need for contraceptives from 28% to 15%.
UNFPA will be Sweden’s, represented by Sida, agreement partner for the Joint Programme. A standard template developed by the UN Development Group (UNDG), Standard Administrative Arrangement (SAA) Joint programmes (Pass-Through Fund Management) which has been established together with Sida as an agreeement template (decision 2015-003649) will be used to regulate Sweden’s support to the Joint UN Programme. The SAA will be signed by Sweden, represented by Sida, and by UNFPA as the Administrative Agent (AA).
In the role as AA, UNFPA is responsible for managing the funds provided to the programme as well as responsible for consolidating the financial reports from the participating UN agencies. UNFPA is also the Convening Agent (CA) for the programme, which means they are responsible for coordination of the programmatic aspects; overall programme coordination, management and monitoring and evaluation (M&E), as well as coordinate the narrative reports. Both UNFPA and UN Women are participating UN organizations under the programme, which means they will both be implementing the programme activities in accordance with their own applicable regulations, rules, policies and procedures, including those relating to procurement as well as the selection and assessment of implementing partners.
UNFPA, as the AA, will disburse funds received from Sida to UN Women, in accordance with instructions from the steering committee, the programme document and approved budget and workplans.. Each organisation will thereafter forward funds to their respective IP’s.
UNFPA and UN Women have signed a Standard Memorandum of Understanding (MoU), which constitutes an annex to the SAA, and where division of responsibilities are clearly defined. The two agencies have agreed through the MoU to establish a coordinating mechanism, a steering committee, to facilitate the effective and efficient collaboration between the UN organizations as well as the Host Government for the implementation of the joint programme. The steering committee will provide oversight and strategic guidance and will be the overall decision body, where decisions regarding the programme, budget and forwarding of funds to respective organization will be handled. Government, CSO, beneficiaries and heads of participating UN agencies will participate in the steering committee. The Embassy of Sweden in Uganda will have an observing role in the steering committee. Consolidated annual financial statements and reports are to be prepared by UNFPA and presented to and approved by the steering committee.

The overall goal of this joint programme is to contribute to the elimination of GBV and improvement of SRHR of women, men, girls and boys, including disadvantaged and vulnerable populations, in Uganda. This will be achieved through four specific programme outcomes: - An enabling policy, legislative and accountability environment for elimination of GBV and improvement of SRHR is translated into action - Reduced social tolerance for Gender Based Violence and improved sexual reproductive health and rights - Increased utilization of quality integrated GBV and SRHR services in the target districts - Strengthened coordination, partnerships, learning and innovation for integrated SRHR and GBV multi-sectoral response and prevention At the end of the five year long joint programme a ten percent decrese is expected in men and women between 15 and 49 years of age who have experienced any form of violence (sexual, physical and/or emotional) during the past 12 months. The teenage pregnancy rate is expected to reduce from 25 percent to 20 percent and the HIV prevalence rate of women and men between 15 and 49 years is expected to decrease from 6 to 5 percent. The joint programme will also contribute to improving the Maternal Mortality Ratio from 336 to 325 deaths per 100 000 live births as well as reducing the unmet need for family planning from 28 to 15 percent.

sector.narrative: Ending violence against women and girls

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.

10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.

10.3 - Säkerställa lika möjligheter och minska förekomsten av ojämlika utfall, bland annat genom att avskaffa diskriminerande lagstiftning, politik och praxis och främja lagstiftning, politik och åtgärder av lämpligt slag i detta hänseende.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.
5.c - Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
5.c - Anta och stärka välgrundad politik och genomförbar lagstiftning för att främja jämställdhet och öka alla kvinnors och flickors egenmakt på alla nivåer

description.narrative: Between 1st January 2019-31st December 2019 UNFPA and UN Women have reported the following key achievements: - Supported the empirical review of the implementation of the Domestic Violence Act 2010 in five districts. - The National policy on Elimination of Gender Based Violence and GBV action plan 2019 were reviewed and printing of policy is underway. - At the institutional level, Gulu University was supported to develop its first ever policy on Sexual Harassment, while Makerere University finalized and disseminated its Sexual Harassment policy. - Supported seven major religious institutions congregating under the Interreligious Council of Uganda (IRCU) to come up with the first time ever joint policy guidance in form of five pastoral letters on: family planning, HIV prevention, maternal health, GBV prevention and teenage pregnancy.- Supported the Ministry of Education & Sports to develop and disseminate the Sexuality Education operational guidelines. - The office of the Director of Public Prosecutions (ODPP) conducted a review of 1,045 SGBV criminal case files in 17 districts which helped realize a 70% conviction rate for GBV cases during the special court sessions, compared to 45% conviction rate in 2018. - At total of 27,352 people were provided with legal assistance by implementing partners. - A total of 10,885 sought assistance from the formal and non-formal justice systems, 73% of the cases were resolved through the non-formal justice system. - All target districts except Kaberamaido district registered over 80% in providing timely life-saving PEP and ECP for survivors of sexual violence. - There was an increase of 18,8% of people who sought care after a sexual violence incident in 2019 as compared to 2018. - It was a positive upward trend in the utilization of other SRHR services, especially post-natal care, new family planning services and re-visits for family planning. - Through outreaches a total of 7,140 people were reached with various services. GBV, HIV/STI’s screening and management, Family planning, HPV, ANC, PNC and psychosocial support in hard-to reach and vulnerable populations. - 2 735 SASA Activists were trained and equipped and reached an estimated 44 827 people through community meetings. - Mobilized and engaged 39,750 people through Male Action Groups (MAGs).- And an estimated 5,159,492 people were reached through multi-media campaigns on their negative use of power and the need to transform negative social norms and attitudes that perpetuate GBV and poor reproductive health outcomes.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Oslocentret har inkommit med en ansökan om 15 MSEK för att stödja ett projekt med syfte att stärka de politiska institutionerna för att de ska bli mer lyhörda, ansvarstagande och transparenta i hela valcykeln. Ambassadens samarbetspartner ska stödja sex politiska partier, samt partiregistraren genom dialog, utbildning, framtagande av riktlinjer och andra viktiga dokument. Projektet ska stödja partierna till att utveckla välfungerande partikommittéer på länsnivå, för att kunna bli mer effektiva i att tillvarata medborgarnas intressen och kunna föra en partilinje i länsregeringarna. Skulle den potentiella grundlagsomröstningen bli av är man beredd att inkludera förberedelser inom sina projektpartners för att medborgarnas intressen ska tillvaratas i den processen.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The Oslo Center has submitted a proposal of 15 MSEK to support a project aiming to strengthen political institutions to enhance responsiveness, accountability and transparency in the electorral cycle. The Embassy cooperation partner will work with six political parties, as well as the Office of the Registrar of Political Parties through dialogues, trainings, development of guidelines and other important documents. The project shall support the parties to develop well functioning political party committess in the counties, to enhance efficiency and becoming more responsive to the interests of the citizens, and to speak with 'one party voice' in the county governments.The project is prepared to include preparations of their partners to include the interests of the citizens in the constitutional referendum process, should it be carried out.
The objective of the project is 'Strengthening Political Institutions to Enhance Responsiveness, Accountability, and Transparency in the Electoral Cycle'.

16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.

description.narrative: Several issues during the reporting period shaped the political environment during implementation. These included interalia; proposed amendments of the constitutional and electoral law, reorganization of political parties, political pacts and emergence of new influential political alliances, heated electoral campaigns, the advent of pseudo-class-based political configuration projecting the political establishment in confrontation with the low-income population christened 'hustler movement.' The Building Bridges Initiative (BBI), a result of the consultations between President Uhuru Kenyatta and the former Prime Minister Raila Odinga in March 2018, culminated in the drive towards constitutional changes. The amendment of the Constitution of Kenya, 2010, via the BBI process may lead to changes to other Acts of Parliament. The BBI report implementation focuses on four thematic areas: a) Policy Development, b) Legislative Process, c) Administrative Action d) Constitutional Amendment. In November and December 2020, a BBI Steering Committee was established, tasked with collecting signatures as approval for the constitutional changes via the BBI process. The secretariat collected 4.4 million signatures from registered voters and presented them to the electoral management body the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) for verification. The IEBC verified 1.33 million signatures, surpassing the constitutional threshold as per Article 257 of Kenya's Constitution of 1 million registered voters. During the Covid-19 crisis period, there was intense internal reorganization of political parties and the parliamentary leadership. The internal struggles and reorganization are connected to the political restructuring towards the 2022 elections. The main proponents of the BBI process, are one faction of the ruling Jubilee Party (JP), and the main opposition party, the Orange Democratic Movement (ODM). Both parties reorganized their leadership in the parliament, It is expected that the BBI process and the eventual constitutional amendments will be conducted in parliament and through popular suffrage. This led to breakaway camps in several political parties, it is expected that structural reorganization of political parties and internal wrangles being experienced in 2020 may continue in 2021 and through to the beginning of 2022. These reorganization may affect implementation of activities, especially among parties entering into coalitions, alliances, or leadership wrangles. The bill proposing changes to political parties' primaries law is already in parliament. Other laws that may be amended as a result of the BBI process include the Elections Act, Political Parties Act, Election Campaign Financing Act, and other Acts and regulations touching on elections' conduct. During the reporting period, the Chief Justice issued an advisory to the President to dissolve parliament for failure to to legislate the implementation of the two-thirds gender principle. The implication and impact of this advisory were multifaceted. It was viewed that the Chief Justice expressively put to the fore frustrations the administration of the rule of law has confronted. However, the executive was believed to have politically been emboldened and powers of the usurped in 'stick and carrot' situation where the executive could easily manipulate parliament because it had powers to dissolve parliament. Religious institutions have gained traction as new avenues to conduct national politics and conduits for patron-clientelist systems. Kenya's politics is predominantly ethnically driven, but a new political convocation is cropping up, the paupers( Hustlers) vs. dynasties (establishment) and has steadily gained traction being accepted, especially by the youth and the public believed to be in the economic margins. This narrative might be a sign of a stronger policy focus where economy and class become more prominent. However, there is no compelling evidence that the country is moving away from tribal politics. Oslo Center activities focused on supporting parties to strengthen their institutions by improving internal democracy; strengthening the relationship between County Assembly MCA's and mainstream parties; and developing guidelines that promote a better understanding of the party's process. The Oslo Center also worked with the Registrar of Political Parties to internally organize the office to regulate and coach political parties. internal party challenges in the party leadership impacted activities uptake with Ford Kenya and Jubilee Party. Amani National Congress (ANC)party leadership met county assembly members to establish linkages between the national assembly and senate members. As a result, the party resolved to establish a technical committee to develop caucus rules and regulations and organize for the county assembly caucus members' leadership elections. the county assembly members Elections were held elections and four women elected to the caucus leadership. The rules provide that the ANC MCA caucus's leadership is is representated at the National Executive Committee (NEC) the highest decision making within a political party. ANC also appointed a new Election Board consisting of 6 men and 5 women. The Kenya African National Union (KANU) party Constitution was last revised in 2013. A National Management Committee (NMC) comprised of members of the parliament, women league, and youth league representatives as well as a legal committee was formed to review the KANU Constitution. The draft changes will be presented to the NEC in December 2020. The Wiper Democratic Movement - Kenya held consultative meetings with the National Executive Committee (NEC) and Parliamentary Group (PG) on party constitutional review. The main areas of amendments include membership recruitment, strengthening the elections board, and vetting candidates for the party and national elections. WDM – Kenya has embraced technology by using SMS, USSD, and online platforms to register its members. The Office of the Registrar of Political Parties (ORPP) developed a detailed proportional electoral system document and presented to the BBI taskforce on mechanisms to address challenges political parties face during primaries and proposals on achieving the 2/3 gender rules and inclusion of youth, PWD's and marginalized and minorities. The strategies also explored proposals for changing the electoral system. KANU, WDM-K, and ANC women leagues developed training material for national and county levels.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative: Several issues during the reporting period shaped the political environment during implementation. These included interalia; proposed amendments of the constitutional and electoral law, reorganization of political parties, political pacts and emergence of new influential political alliances, heated electoral campaigns, the advent of pseudo-class-based political configuration projecting the political establishment in confrontation with the low-income population christened 'hustler movement.' The Building Bridges Initiative (BBI), a result of the consultations between President Uhuru Kenyatta and the former Prime Minister Raila Odinga in March 2018, culminated in the drive towards constitutional changes. The amendment of the Constitution of Kenya, 2010, via the BBI process may lead to changes to other Acts of Parliament. The BBI report implementation focuses on four thematic areas: a) Policy Development, b) Legislative Process, c) Administrative Action d) Constitutional Amendment. In November and December 2020, a BBI Steering Committee was established, tasked with collecting signatures as approval for the constitutional changes via the BBI process. The secretariat collected 4.4 million signatures from registered voters and presented them to the electoral management body the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) for verification. The IEBC verified 1.33 million signatures, surpassing the constitutional threshold as per Article 257 of Kenya's Constitution of 1 million registered voters. During the Covid-19 crisis period, there was intense internal reorganization of political parties and the parliamentary leadership. The internal struggles and reorganization are connected to the political restructuring towards the 2022 elections. The main proponents of the BBI process, are one faction of the ruling Jubilee Party (JP), and the main opposition party, the Orange Democratic Movement (ODM). Both parties reorganized their leadership in the parliament, It is expected that the BBI process and the eventual constitutional amendments will be conducted in parliament and through popular suffrage. This led to breakaway camps in several political parties, it is expected that structural reorganization of political parties and internal wrangles being experienced in 2020 may continue in 2021 and through to the beginning of 2022. These reorganization may affect implementation of activities, especially among parties entering into coalitions, alliances, or leadership wrangles. The bill proposing changes to political parties' primaries law is already in parliament. Other laws that may be amended as a result of the BBI process include the Elections Act, Political Parties Act, Election Campaign Financing Act, and other Acts and regulations touching on elections' conduct. During the reporting period, the Chief Justice issued an advisory to the President to dissolve parliament for failure to to legislate the implementation of the two-thirds gender principle. The implication and impact of this advisory were multifaceted. It was viewed that the Chief Justice expressively put to the fore frustrations the administration of the rule of law has confronted. However, the executive was believed to have politically been emboldened and powers of the usurped in 'stick and carrot' situation where the executive could easily manipulate parliament because it had powers to dissolve parliament. Religious institutions have gained traction as new avenues to conduct national politics and conduits for patron-clientelist systems. Kenya's politics is predominantly ethnically driven, but a new political convocation is cropping up, the paupers( Hustlers) vs. dynasties (establishment) and has steadily gained traction being accepted, especially by the youth and the public believed to be in the economic margins. This narrative might be a sign of a stronger policy focus where economy and class become more prominent. However, there is no compelling evidence that the country is moving away from tribal politics. Oslo Center activities focused on supporting parties to strengthen their institutions by improving internal democracy; strengthening the relationship between County Assembly MCA's and mainstream parties; and developing guidelines that promote a better understanding of the party's process. The Oslo Center also worked with the Registrar of Political Parties to internally organize the office to regulate and coach political parties. internal party challenges in the party leadership impacted activities uptake with Ford Kenya and Jubilee Party. Amani National Congress (ANC)party leadership met county assembly members to establish linkages between the national assembly and senate members. As a result, the party resolved to establish a technical committee to develop caucus rules and regulations and organize for the county assembly caucus members' leadership elections. the county assembly members Elections were held elections and four women elected to the caucus leadership. The rules provide that the ANC MCA caucus's leadership is is representated at the National Executive Committee (NEC) the highest decision making within a political party. ANC also appointed a new Election Board consisting of 6 men and 5 women. The Kenya African National Union (KANU) party Constitution was last revised in 2013. A National Management Committee (NMC) comprised of members of the parliament, women league, and youth league representatives as well as a legal committee was formed to review the KANU Constitution. The draft changes will be presented to the NEC in December 2020. The Wiper Democratic Movement - Kenya held consultative meetings with the National Executive Committee (NEC) and Parliamentary Group (PG) on party constitutional review. The main areas of amendments include membership recruitment, strengthening the elections board, and vetting candidates for the party and national elections. WDM – Kenya has embraced technology by using SMS, USSD, and online platforms to register its members. The Office of the Registrar of Political Parties (ORPP) developed a detailed proportional electoral system document and presented to the BBI taskforce on mechanisms to address challenges political parties face during primaries and proposals on achieving the 2/3 gender rules and inclusion of youth, PWD's and marginalized and minorities. The strategies also explored proposals for changing the electoral system. KANU, WDM-K, and ANC women leagues developed training material for national and county levels.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: UNICEF Strengthened protection of girls and boys' human rights in Guatemala
UNICEF Stärkt skydd av utsatta flickor och pojkars rättigheter i Guatemala

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Syftet med insatsen är att genom förebyggande arbete minska antalet barn och ungdomar som utsätts för våld, övergrepp eller försummelse, och att förbättra statliga institutioners förmåga att skydda och stödja barn som far illa.
UNICEF kommer att genomföra programmet i samarbete med organisationer från det civila samhället som har gedigen erfarenhet av att arbeta med barnrättsfrågor och förändringsarbete, och som kompletterar FN-organets egna internationella expertis med lokal kunskap och geografisk räckvidd (Refugio de la Niñez, Fundación Sobrevivientes, Misioneros San Carlos de Scalabrinianis, och Instituto de Enseñanza para el Desarrollo Sostenible).
Programmet kommer framförallt att inriktas på barn från marginaliserade och utsatta grupper i landsbygdsområden i 13 av landets 22 provinser (Alta Verapaz, Baja Verapaz, Chimaltenango, Chiquimula, Escuintla, Izabal, Jalapa, Quetzaltenango, Quiche, San Marcos, Solola, Totonicapan och Guatemala). Som ett resultat av insatsen förväntas drygt hälften av landets 340 kommuner att ha fungerande skyddssystem på plats, där offentliga och privata aktörer samverkar för att förebygga våld och för att tidigt fånga upp och stödja utsatta barn. I 20 av kommunerna kommer programmet dessutom att genomföra en särskild satsning för att utveckla system och kapacitet för skydd av utsatta barn i 200 lokalsamhällen, i samarbete med det lokala näringslivet, lokala ledare och civilsamhället. För att åstadkomma dessa resultat kommer UNICEF och deras partners att arbeta både direkt med barn och deras vårdnadshavare, och med statliga institutioner.
I det direkta arbetet med barn och vårdnadshavare kommer programmet att främja gott föräldraskap, respekt för barns rättigheter och barns deltagande i beslut som rör deras liv. Programmet kommer särskilt att ta i beaktande barn med funktionsvariation, barn till diskriminerade befolkningsgrupper, barn som växer upp i fängelse (barn till fängslade mödrar), barn i migration, och HBTQIA+ ungdomar.
Arbetet med att stärka det institutionella ramverket kommer framförallt att genomföras i samarbete med Utbildnings-, Hälso-, Social- och Utrikesministerierna, Ombudspersonen för Mänskliga Rättigheter, Nationella Adoptionsrådet, Sekretariatet för Social Välfärd, Kongressen, Polismyndigheten, Åklagarmyndigheten och Domstolsväsendet. Programmet kommer att erbjuda tekniskt stöd, metodutveckling, utbildning och rådgivning samt viss infrastruktur för att förbättra lagar, institutionell kapacitet och samordning mellan myndigheter.
Programmets totala beräknade budget uppgår till ungefär 90 miljoner kronor, varav UNICEF kommer bidra med 10 miljoner. Sida kommer att stödja programmet med 80 miljoner kronor. Denna finansiering utgör närmare 80 procent av UNICEF:s totala programlinje för skydd av utsatta barn i Guatemala.
Sida kommer i sin dialog med UNICEF och i uppföljningen i programmet att lägga särskild vikt vid UNICEF:s förmåga att anpassa verksamheten till lokala kulturella förhållanden (inklusive mayaspråk) och att integrera jämställdhetsperspektivet. Sida kommer också att noga följa upp huruvida programmet bidrar till att stärka de civilsamhällsorganisationer som tillsammans med UNICEF genomför programmet och hur väl anpassade UNICEF:s samarbetsformer är för detta syfte.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The purpose of the initiative is to reduce the number of children and adolescents exposed to violence, abuse or neglect through prevention, and to improve the ability of state institutions to protect and support children.
Unicef ??will implement the program in collaboration with civil society organizations that have solid experience in working with child rights issues, complementing UNICEF with important thematic expertise and geographical scope (Refugio de la Niñez, Fundación Sobrevivientes, Misioneros San Carlos de Scalabrinianis and Instituto de Enseñanza para el Desarrollo Sostenible).The program will focus primarily on children from marginalized and vulnerable groups in rural areas in 13 of the 22 provinces (Alta Verapaz, Baja Verapaz, Chimaltenango, Chiquimula, Escuintla, Izabal, Jalapa, Quetzaltenango, Quiche, San Marcos, Solola, Totonicapan and Guatemala).
As a result, more than half of the country's 340 municipalities are expected to have effective on-site protection systems, where public and private actors work together to prevent violence against children, and detect and support vulnerable children. In addition, in 20 municipalities, the program will carry out a special effort to develop systems and capacity for the protection of vulnerable children in 200 local communities, in cooperation with local business, local leaders and civil society. In order to achieve these results, UNICEF and their partners will work directly with children and their guardians, and with state institutions.
In the direct work with children and their guardians, the program will promote good parenting, respect for children's rights, and children's participation in decisions concerning their lives. The program will take into account, in particular, children with disabilities, children of discriminated populations, children who grow up in prisons (children of detained mothers), migrant children, and HBTQIA+ adolescents.
Efforts to strengthen the institutional framework will be carried out in cooperation with Ministry of Education, Health, Social Affairs and Foreign Affairs, Human Rights Ombudsman, National Adoption Council, Secretariat for Social Welfare, the Congress, National Police, the Prosecutor's Office and the Judicial Branch. The program will provide technical support, develop procedures and methodologies, offer training and advisory services, as well as support law reforms, institutional capacity building and coordination between responsbile authorities.
The program's total estimated budget amounts to approximately SEK 90 million, of which UNICEF will contribute 10 million. Sida will support the program by SEK 80 million. This funding accounts for nearly 80 percent of UNICEF's total program for the protection of vulnerable children in Guatemala.
In its dialogue with UNICEF and in the follow-up in the program, Sida will pay particular attention to UNICEF's ability to adapt its activities to local cultural conditions (including maya language) and to integrate gender equality. Sida will also carefully monitor whether the program contributes to strengthening civil society organizations which, together with UNICEF, implement the program and how well UNICEF's cooperation forms are for this purpose.

The proposed development intervention aims that by end of 2022, girls, boys and adolescents, particularly indigenous children and youth, have reduced their risk of suffering violence, enjoy protective environments and a system that protects their rights. The goal will be achieved through four specific objectives: 1) girls, boys, families and civil society in prioritized communities increase their capacities to prevent violence against children through change of social norms and practises; 2) girls, boys and adolescents of 50% of the municipalities in Guatemala have access to Municipal Child and Adolescent Protection Systems; 3) in four provinces, girls, boys and adolescent victims of violence have access to special protection services, specific for children, which apply international standards aimed to establish the superior interest of the child; and 4) in four provinces, girls, boys and adolescents have access to a system of specialized justice for the special protection of children and adolescents. By the end of the intervention, 20 prioritized municipalities will have Community Protection Committees; in 200 communities, parents and tutors of children will have learnt good parenting skills based on respect of child rights; girls and adolescent girls in 20 prioritized municipalities practise self-protection against abuse and exploitation while actively participating in spaces where decisions about the exercise of their rights are made; 50% of all municipal governments have installed capacity to implement Comprehensive Child and Adolescent Protection Systems according to international child protection standards to prevent violence against children; a model to promote special protection of children in vulnerable urban areas is validated; the Secretariat for Social Well-Being, which is the governing body for child special protection, provides services according to international standards; state ministries accountable for social protection have validated a guide to apply international standards in the provision of special protection services for children; Ministry of Foreign Affairs and governing bodies for special protection and migration have tools to provide care and protection to migrant children according to international standards; the National Adoption Council has management mechanisms that favor family preservation; state of Guatemala has capacity to develop a National De-institutionalization Strategy; the Office of the Human Rights Ombudsman enhances its capacity in ten provinces to observe compliance with international standards on special protection in public and private contexts; Congress of Guatemala has adapted relevant legislation to international standards; the National Police has capacity to carry out specialized criminal investigation for child victims of violence and adolescents in conflict with the law; the Office of the Public Prosecutor has developed specialized crime investigation and prosecution models in four provinces that favor protection of child victims; the Judicial Branch applies and monitors compliance of judicial decisions with international standards at child, family and criminal courts.

tag.narrative: 16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.

description.narrative: While the previous UNICEF programs have focused largely on strengthening institutional child protection capacity and creation of municipal protection system, one of the innovative objects of the new UNICEF program is the development and formulation of community prevention model with direct participation of parents, youth and children themselves. Since the national child protection system still has serious challenges, focus has been placed on prevention at community level. To that end, during the first year of implementation, UNICEF carried out important base line studies to establish intervention priorities y methodologies for community level intervention. During 2019, sensitization and training was carried out in 100 rural communities in 25 prioritized municipalities of four provinces. Communication for Development (C4D) has been integrated as a tool to promote social and behavioral change at individual, family and community levels; a Diploms course on C4D for 150 child protection professionals in coordination with Landivar University was carried out in 2019. 2019 was an election year in Guatemala and UNICEF carried out 104 events with 667 candidates in municipal elections; 99% of the candidates signed a letter of engagement in favor of child rights. Another innovative and challenging program objective is to develop child protection intervention model in vulnerable urban settings. To that end, an agreement was signed with the Mayor of municipality of Mixco in the outskirts of Guatemala City to establish a municipal child protection office. Activities were carried out in communities marked by high levels of youth gang violence, violence against children and youth, drugs, poverty, unemployment, high population density and large number of at-risk youth. Training was provided for 40 officers of the Municipal Police and Municipal Transit Police, who may accompany activities in high risk communities and are a first resource of protection for child and youth victims of violence at their communities. The migrant caravans of January-February 2019 with an estimated 15,000 poeple passing through Guatemala presented a humanitarian crises involving an estimated 3,000 children and adolescents, mainly from El Salvador and Honduras. UNICEF and its local partners activated a humanitarian response system, providing meals, personal hygiene systems and psychological attention in Guatemala City and Tecun Uman at the Mexican border. State institutions' capacity to attend migrant children and youth was strengthened through protocols of attention based on international human rights standards. Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Guatemala received support in providing psycho-social attention to children at consulates in Arizona and Texas, and in implementing an informative campaign for migrant children and youth on the migration process; the campaign has been translated to three Mayan languages and is used both in Guatemala and Mexico. UNICEF also supported the First Lady's Social Works Office in the design and implementation of protocols for attention of returned/deported children and youth; during 2019, up to 300 families per month were deported from Mexico by land. In relation to specialized justice and state institutions responsible for child protection, UNICEF continued working with the National Civilian Police force, providing nation wide training to police officers in application of special procedures, protocols and guidelines when dealing with cases of violence against children and youth, or with youth in conflict with the law, respecting international human rights standards. In the Judicial System, the program contributed to an important positive change in judicial processes related to consented divorce and child support, accomplishing an 80% reduction in time for emission of sentences, thus improving child welfare.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UNDPs landprogram 2018-2022 är inriktat på att säkra en varaktig fred för att bygga effektiva nationella och subnationella institutioner för att ta itu med omedelbara behov i alla Myanmars samhällen, bygga det förtroende som krävs för att stödja en eventuell politisk lösning efter decennier av konflikt, och förbereda institutioner för ökad decentralisering i linje med en eventuell fredsuppgörelse. Därför måste styrningsmekanismer minska riskerna för konflikter som orsakas av ojämlikhet, uteslutning och sårbarhet i samband med klimatförändringar och naturresurshantering.
Av sex projekt har Sektionskontoret beslutat att stödja två av dem, SERIP - Projekt för stöd till Effektiva och Responsiva Institutioner; och LEAP - Ledarskap, Effektivitet, Anpassningsbarhet och Professionalism i Myanmar Civil Service, med sammanlagt 60 MSEK över tre år, 2018-2020. SERIP syftar till att stärka effektiviteten hos statliga verkställande och lagstiftande institutioner för att förstå Myanmars folks behov och önskemål, med all sin mångfald men också växande ojämlikheter, samt att formulera, genomföra och utvärdera politiken samt att utnyttja de offentliga resurserna på ett sätt som ger effektiva, aktuella och rättvisa svar till dessa ambitioner.
Det svenska stödet till landprogrammet uppgår till 60 MSEK. Vidare kommer ett stöd på 1 MSEK att beviljas för perioden 2018-2019 till det CPG-sekretariatet, gruppen för samarbetspartners, som sköts av UNDP.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The Country Program 2018-2022 is focused on securing a durable peace to build effective national and sub-national institutions to address the immediate needs of all of Myanmar’s communities, build the trust necessary to underpin an eventual political settlement to decades of conflict, and prepare institutions for increased decentralization in line with an eventual peace settlement. In so doing, governance mechanisms must mitigate conflict risks posed by inequality, exclusion, and vulnerability linked to climate change and natural resource management.
Out of six projects, the Section Office has decided to support two; SERIP - Support to Effective and Responsive Institutions Project; and LEAP - Leadership, Effectiveness, Adaptability and Professionalism in Myanmar’s Civil Service, with a total amount of 60 MSEK over three years, 2018-2020. SERIP aims at strengthening the effectiveness of state executive and legislative institutions in understanding the needs and aspirations of the Myanmar people , in all its diversity but also growing inequalities, and in formulating, implementing and evaluating policies, as well as appropriating public resources in a way that provides effective, timely and equitable respopnses to these aspirations.
The Swedish support to the programme amounts to 60 MSEK. Furthermore, a contribution of 1 MSEK is granted for the period of 2018-2019 to the Cooperation Partner Group Secretariat, hosted by UNDP.

SERIP Output 1: Governance institutions have access to accurate, comprehensive and harmonized data needed for decision-making and monitoring. Output 2: Policy formulation, implementation and monitoring at Union and S/R level is guided by strategic priorities, better coordinated and more inclusive. Output 3: Parliaments are equipped to pass robust and people-centred legislation resulting from effective policy-making and legislative proposals. Output 4: Subnational institutions have gained autonomy and skills for demand-driven and decentralized public-sector management, with emphasis on improving equitable access to services, building resilience and fostering social cohesion. LEAP Output 1: Ethics, meritocracy, inclusivity and responsiveness applied in Myanmar Civil Service. Output 2: People centred services enhanced due to more effective and professional civil service. Output 3: Civil service oversight, accountability, standards and capacity strengthened to support decentralisation at Union and sub-natiolnal levels.

title.narrative: Decision on contribution UNDP Country Programme 2018-2020

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Sida ger stöd till UN Women i Uganda för att bidra till genomförandet av UNW:s landprogram ("UNW Uganda Country Office Strategic Plan and Programme 2019-2022"). Planen innefattar fyra tematiska områden och fyra interna organisationsutvecklingsområden:
1: Kvinnors möjlighet att leda, delta i och att dra likvärdig nytta av olika system för samhällsstyrning, 2: Kvinnors inkomstsäkerhet, rätt till anständigt arbete och ekonomisk självständighet, 3: Kvinnors och flickors rätt att leva ett liv fritt från alla former av våld, 4: Kvinnors och flickors möjligheter till inflytande för att bidra till hållbar fred och deras möjligheter att dra lika nytta av förebyggande arbete avseende naturkatastrofer och konflikter samt av humanitära insatser. • Mer effektiv samordning och fler strategiska partnerskap mellan FN-organisationer för att främja jämställdhet mellan kvinnor och män, • Ökat engagemang av partners för att stödja UNW:s mandat, • Program av hög kvalitet som bygger på kunskap, innovation, resultatbaserad ledning och utvärdering, • Förbättrad organisatorisk effektivitet med fokus på kapacitetsbyggande på land- och projektnivå.
Sida tillhandahåller icke-öronmärkt stöd på 60 miljoner kronor till UNW för att genomföra landprogrammet i Uganda under perioden 2020-2022. Flera givare bidrar till UNW:s verksamhet i Uganda, främst genom projektstöd.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 UNW has requested support for the implementation of the UN Women Country Office Strategic Plan and Programme 2019-2022 in Uganda. The country programme is aligned with the UNDAF in Uganda and the national development plan, national legislation and policies for gender equality, and the global UN Women strategy. It focuses on four thematic areas and four areas of organisational effectiveness and efficiency; 1: Women lead, participate in and benefit equally from governance systems, 2: Women have income security, decent work and economic autonomy, 3: All women and girls live a life free from all forms of violence, 4: Women and girls contribute and have a greater influence in building sustainable peace and resilience, and benefit equally from the prevention of natural disasters and conflicts, and from humanitarian action. • more effective and efficient UN system coordination and strategic partnerships on gender equality and women's empowerment, • Increased engagement of partners in support of UN Women's mandate, • High quality programmes through knowledge, innovation, results-based management and evaluation, • Enhanced organisational effectiveness, with a focus on robust capacity and efficiency at country and project level.
Sida provides non-earmarked support of SEK 60 million to UNW for implementing the programme in Uganda during the period 2020-2022. Several donors are funding UNW's operations in Uganda, primarily with project support.

Programme Focus: DEVELOPMENT RESULTS Impact area 1: Women lead, participate in and benefit equally from governance systems • Outcome 1.1: Women engage in political institutions and processes. • Outcome 1.2: National and Local Plans and budgets are gender responsive • Outcome 1.3: Policy and Financial Environment to track GEWE • Outcome 1.4: Gender statistics to monitor policies and reporting commitments under SDGs • Outcome 1.5: Gender statistics used by different players to inform advocacy, policies and programmes Impact area 2: Women have income security, decent work and economic autonomy• Outcome 2.1: Public and private procurement is gender responsive, • Outcome 2.2: Climate smart agricultural policies are gender responsive and women’s land tenure security is increased. Impact area 3: All women and girls live a life free from all forms of violence • Outcome 3.1: An enabling legislative and policy environment in line with international standards on EVAWG, Women’s Access to Justice, and other forms of discrimination is in place and translated into action, • Outcome 3.2: Favorable social norms, attitudes and behaviors are promoted at community and individual levels to prevent VAWG and end child marriage, • Outcome 3.3: Increased use of available accessible and quality essential services by women and girls who experience violence. Impact area 4: Women and girls contribute and have a greater influence in building sustainable peace and resilience, and benefit equally from the prevention of natural disasters and conflicts and from humanitarian action • Outcome 4.1: More commitments on women, peace and security are implemented by GoU and the UN, and more gender equality advocates influence peace and security processes, • Outcome 4.2: Women benefit from Humanitarian action in the context of refugee response. ORGANSATIONAL DEVELOPMENTS • More effective and efficient UN system coordination and strategic partnerships on gender equality and women's empowerment, • Increased engagement of partners in support of UN Women's mandate, • High quality programmes through knowledge, innovation, results-based management and evaluation, • Enhanced organisational effectiveness, with a focus on robust capacity and efficiency at country and project level.

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Den föreslagna insatsen kommer att stärka skyddet av mänskliga rättigheter i Liberia och försöka påverka de strukturella och systemiska brister – i politiken, i verkställandet av beslut, och i lagstiftningen – som idag bidrar till ökade kränkningar av de mänskliga rättigheterna. Rätts- och säkerhetssystemet i Liberia har fått alltmer kritik för låg efterlevnad av de mänskliga rättigheterna, inklusive polis, domstolar och rättsvårdande instanser.
Liberias oberoende nationella kommission för mänskliga rättigheter (INCHR) skapades 2005 för främjande och skydd av mänskliga rättigheter i Liberia, som ett resultat av fredsavtalet (CPA) 2003. INCHR inrättades i linje med Paris-principerna för nationella MR-institutioner. Trots dess tillkomst 2005 blev inte kommissionen verksam förrän 2010. Stödet till INCHR kommer att göra det möjligt att utreda kränkningar av de mänskliga rättigheterna, främja utbildning av mänskliga rättigheter och stödja förebyggande mekanismer.
OHCHR är det ledande FN-organet för mänskliga rättigheter. År 1993 bemyndigade generalförsamlingen både Högkommissarien för mänskliga rättigheter och OHCHR med ett unikt mandat för att främja och skydda alla mänskliga rättigheter för alla människor. Genom Human Rights and Protection Service (HRPS)(UNMIL) har OHCHR varit engagerad i integrationen och institutionaliseringen av de mänskliga rättigheterna i Liberia sedan 2003.Inför den planerade stängningen av UNMIL (United Nations Mission in Liberia) i mars 2019 inrättades OHCHR-Liberias fristående landkontor för att bidra till konsolideringen av de framsteg som gjorts efter UNMIL och för att säkerställa varaktig fred, försoning och konfliktförebyggande. OHCHR undertecknade sitt värdlands-avtal med Liberias regering den 1 april 2018. I Liberia är OHCHR den enda FN-organisationen som har mandat att övervaka MR, rapportera om sina resultat och ge tekniskt bistånd till statliga institutioner och organisationer i det civila samhället utifrån resultaten.
Det övergripande målet med den föreslagna insatsen är att "förbättra skyddet för mänskliga rättigheter och därmed främja hållbar fred i Liberia". I enlighet med Parisprinciperna för MR-institutioner behöver INCHR bli en oberoende och trovärdig institution i befolkningens ögon. För detta ändamål kommer insatsen att stärka INCHRs interna institutionella system i syfte att uppnå organisationseffektivitet och professionalism. INCHRs kapacitet att utbilda, distribuera, utrusta och leda MR-övervakare i Liberias alla 15 län kommer att förbättras för att säkerställa dess närvaro utanför Monrovia, vilket är nödvändigt för att uppnå trovärdig övervakning, dokumentation och rapportering om MR. Därutöver kommer OHCHRs övervakning av MR-situationen i Liberia – både separat och i samverkan med INCHR – förbättra respekten för MR vad gäller frihetsberövade personer och personer i kontakt med rättsväsendet. Väl fungerande rättsinstanser och förbättrad tillgång till rättvisa för alla väntas öka förtroendet för staten på såväl nationell som lokal nivå.
Följande fem resultat ska således uppnås:
- Öka kapaciteten hos INCHR för att fullgöra sitt mandat att övervaka och rapportera mänskliga rättigheter och öka ansvarsutkrävandet för statliga instanser (’duty-bearers’) samt tillgång till rättvisa för medborgarna/rättighetsbärarna (’rights-holders’).
- Förbättra INCHRs kapacitet att engagera och samarbeta med CSOs så att rösterna från marginaliserade och diskriminerade grupper hörs.
- Öka INCHRs närvaro ute i landet (samtliga 15 länen) med kvalificerad, utbildad och välutrustad fältpersonal för att skydda de mänskliga rättigheterna över hela landet.
- Öka INCHRs kapacitet att integrera jämställdhet och säkerställa större synlighet för kvinnors och flickors rättigheter i opinionsbildning, policyer och den egna verksamheten.
- Öka INCHRs interna institutionella kapacitet för att förbättra ansvarsutkrävande och öppenhet, skapa bättre styrningsprocesser och öka dess förmåga att internt och externt samordna MR-frågorna.
Ambassaden bedömer att projektet utgått från fattigas människors perspektiv, och drar slutsatsen att en situation där de mänskliga rättigheterna i Liberia förbättrats kommer att stärka personer som lever i fattigdom, hjälpa till att undanröja orättvisor och andra hinder som påverkar deras rättvisa tillgång till tjänster, möjligheter och resurser, och därmed bidra till att minska fattigdomen.
Avtalet kommer att undertecknas med OHCHR som avtalspartner. En viktig aspekt av avtalet utgörs av det stöd som OHCHR ska erbjuda INCHR. OHCHR förväntas underteckna ett samarbetsavtal/MoU med INCHR för att reglera dess tekniska assistans och annat stöd till INCHR inom ramen för detta program.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The proposed intervention will support the protection of the rights of citizens and residents of Liberia and address the structural and systemic gaps in policies, practices and legislation that escalate human rights violations. The justice and security system in Liberia has received increased criticism for its lack of compliance with human rights standards including the police, courts and correction services.
The Independent National Commission on Human Rights (INCHR) of Liberia was established in 2005 for the promotion and protection of human rights in Liberia, as a result of the Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA) in 2003. INCHR was set up in line with the Paris Principles as a national HR institution. Although established in 2005, the Commission was not functional until 2010. The support to the INCHR will enable the institution to investigate human rights violations, promote human rights education and support preventive mechanisms.
OHCHR is the lead UN entity on human rights. In 1993, the General Assembly entrusted both the High Commissioner for Human Rights and OHCHR with a unique mandate to promote and protect all human rights for all people. Through the Human Rights and Protection Service (HRPS) section of the United Nations Mission in Liberia (UNMIL), OHCHR has been engaged in the integration and institutionalization of human rights in Liberia since 2003. In anticipation of the closure of the United Nations Mission in Liberia (UNMIL) in March 2019, the OHCHR Liberia stand-alone country office was established to contribute to the consolidation of achievements made after UNMIL and to ensure sustained peace, reconciliation and conflict prevention. OHCHR signed its host country agreement with the Government of Liberia on 1 April 2018. OHCHR is the only UN entity in the country with a comprehensive mandate to monitor human rights, report on its findings, and provide technical assistance to State institutions and civil society organizations based on its findings.
The overall objective of the proposed intervention is “enhancing human rights protection to promote sustainable peace in Liberia”. In line with the Paris Principles for National Human Rights Institutions, the INCHR needs to become an independent and credible institutions in the eyes of the population. To this end, the proposed intervention will strengthen the internal institutional systems of the INCHR with the view to achieving organisational efficiency, effectiveness and accountability. The capacity of the INCHR to train, deploy, equip and supervise human rights monitors in all 15 counties of Liberia will be enhanced to ensure its presence outside Monrovia, necessary to achieve credible human rights monitoring, documentation and reporting that meets minimal standard of professionalism. In addition, the independent monitoring of the human rights situation in Liberia by the OHCHR separately as well as in conjunction with the INCHR is expected to enhance the improvement of the respect of human rights of persons in detention and of persons coming into contact with the security and justice system. Well-functioning redress mechanisms and access to remedies for persons who feel aggrieved by the State and its institutions will enhance confidence in the State at both national and local levels.
Thus, the following five outcomes are expected to be achieved:
- To increase the capacity of the Independent National Commission on Human Rights to fulfil its mandate to monitor and report human rights and to enhance the accountability of duty-bearers and access to remedy for rights-holders.
- To enhance INCHR’s capacity to engage and collaborate with CSOs so that the voices of marginalised and discriminated groups are heard.
- To increase INCHR’s county level presence with qualified, trained and well-resourced field staff to ensure the protection of human rights across the country.
- To increase INCHR’s capacity to mainstream gender and ensure greater visibility to the rights of women and girls in its advocacy, policies and operations.
- To increase INCHR’s internal institutional capacity to improve accountability and transparency to enhance good governance and its ability to internally and externally coordinate human rights issues.
The Embassy assesses that the project has taken into consideration the poor people's perspective and concludes that improved human rights accountability in Liberia will have benefits for people living in poverty and help to remove injustice and other barriers that affect their fair access to services, opportunities and resources, and thus contributing to reducing poverty.
The agreement will be signed with OHCHR as the agreement partner. A major aspect of the agreement entails support by OHCHR to INCHR. OHCHR will be expected to sign a cooperation agreement/MoU with the INCHR to regulate its technical and other assistance to the INCHR within the framework of this programme.

The support to OHCHR is directed at achieving the following four outcomes/objectives: Outcome 1: to increase the capacity of INCHR to fulfil its mandate to monitor and report human rights and enhance accountability of duty bearers and access to remedy for right holders. Outcome 2: to enhance INHCR's capacity to engage and collaborate with CSOs so that the voices of marginalized and discriminated groups are heard and with relevant government departments to facilitate cooperation with and among them to ensure greater opportunities for designing interventions and strategies for corrective action. Outcome 3: to increase INHCR's county level presence with qualified, trained and well-resourced field staff to ensure the protection of human rights across the country. Outcome 4: to increased INHCR's capacity to mainstream gender and ensure greater visibility to the rights of women and girls in its advocacy, policies, operations, and activities. Outcome 5: to increase INHCR internal institutional capacity to improve accountability and transparency

participating-org.narrative: United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (extrabudgetary contributions only)

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.
16.2 - End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.

16.a - Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.

16.a - Stärka berörda nationella institutioner, bland annat genom internationellt samarbete, i syfte att bygga upp kapacitet på alla nivåer, i synnerhet i utvecklingsländerna, för att förebygga våld och bekämpa terrorism och brottslighet.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

description.narrative: Outcome 1: to increase the capacity of INCHR to fulfil its mandate to monitor and report human rights and enhance accountability of duty bearers and access to remedy for right holders. Indicator 1: Extent to which NHRI has been established and/or works in conformity with international standards (Paris Principles)- Target: INCHR continues to maintains ‘A’ status rating by accreditation Committee- Achieved: INCHR still holds an “A” status from the last GANHRI Assessment, which was done in 2016 and accredited A Status in March 2017. The next assessment will be done in 2021. Indicator 1.1. Number of allegations of human rights violation complaints or cases registered, investigated and adjudicated.- Target for 2019: 23 previous cases concluded and an additional 60 new cases investigated and documented in 2019;- Achieved: INCHR recorded 130 new cases in 2019. Out of these, 60 cases were investigated and documented, 23 cases were concluded. OHCHR provided technical support to INCHR and Civil Society Organisation Human Rights Advocacy Platform (CSO-HRAP) to carry out two facts-finding missions. The missions revealed many human rights concerns in the counties visited. The data collected formed part of the INCHR Annual Human Rights Situation Report. Among the interventions generated by the mission is the enhanced advocacy for the mobilisation of criminal courts to conduct criminal proceedings within the prisons compound. Because of this mechanism, 77 pre-trial detainees who had spent many years in detention were released through the process. Outcome 2: to enhance INHCR's capacity to engage and collaborate with CSOs so that the voices of marginalized and discriminated groups are heard and with relevant government departments to facilitate cooperation with and among them to ensure greater opportunities for designing interventions and strategies for corrective action. Indicator 2. Number of CSOs and marginalised groups, right-holders, especially women and discriminated groups, whose capacities have been strengthened to claim their rights.- Target: Two NGO networks will sign a comprehensive partnership strategy with INCHR to inform joint collaboration in promotion and protection of human rights in 2019.- Achieved: INCHR engaged with 15 CSOs and 10 professional bodies/national institutions on human rights for marginalised and discriminated groups. The INCHR and CSOs ensured that the public protests remained peaceful and that the protests would not violate the rights of other persons in Liberia. During the year, OHCHR had provided training on all forms of monitoring including protests, and, during the 7 June 2019 protests, OHCHR supported the deployment of well-trained INCHR and CSOs members to monitor the protest. Outcome 3: to increase INHCR's county level presence with qualified, trained and well-resourced field staff to ensure the protection of human rights across the country. Indicator 3. INCHR institutional capacities (human resources and field presence) strengthened to accomplish human rights promotion and protection mandate- Target: In 2019, two additional professional staff with expertise in Finance and Gender are recruited.- Achieved: OHCHR supported the recruitment of three regional coordinators, one investigator, one Hearing Officer, one Complaint Clerk and fourteen Human Rights Monitors, enhancing INCHR’s county presence. Focus was placed on improving staff with human rights expertise, which explains why no finance expert was recruited. 38 INCHR Staff, 620 CSO members and journalists, were trained.o 15 trainings organized to enhance the capacity of INCHR and CSO Monitors and journalists on human rights monitoring, investigation, receiving and recording of human rights complaints. Outcome 4: to increased INHCR's capacity to mainstream gender and ensure greater visibility to the rights of women and girls in its advocacy, policies, operations, and activities. Indicator 4: INCHR staff capacities strengthened to mainstream gender aspects in its policies and plans in line with international human rights standards and principles.- Target: In 2019, One Local gender expert will be hired to strengthen gender unit; OHCHR will facilitate one International gender expert to provide technical backstopping and support supervision to backstop INCHR gender staff. Indicator 4.1. Number of INCHR staff trained on gender mainstreaming in policies, plans and programmes- Target: In 2019, 50 INCHR staff will be oriented on gender mainstreaming in programmes and policies; gender considerations will be taken into account during the revision of two core INCHR policy documents (revised strategic plan and human resource policies).- Achieved:o 1 Gender and Diversity Officer recruited 1 National Gender consultant recruitment ongoingo With the support of OHCHR, INCHR was instrumental in the passage of the Domestic Violence Bill, which was passed into law in August 2019 under the title, “An Act to Amend Title 26, Chapter 16” of The Penal Law. The positive responses emanating from the recommendations made to the Government by the INCHR are as follows:- The Domestic Violence Bill was passed into law. This is in fulfilment of Liberia’s international human rights commitment, including its obligation under CEDAW.- A National Colloquium with Government Ministries, Agencies Corporation and CSOs was held to seek views of the citizens on the accountability and impunity of perpetrators of the civil wars, and how the TRC recommendations can be implemented. The colloquium resulted in a draft bill for the establishment of the Economic and War Crimes court for Liberia.- With support from OHCHR, INCHR successfully advocated for the dropping of the tenure bill which would have compromised the independence of INCHR and violated the provisions of the Paris principle on NHRIs. Outcome 5: to increase INHCR internal institutional capacity to improve accountability and transparency OHCHR supported the hiring of Price Waterhouse Coopers(pwc), an audit firm, to conduct the INCHR internal review of management systems. The report on findings and recommendations was submitted to INCHR, OHCHR and the Embassy of Sweden in March 2020. The overall outcome of the review indicated significant flaws in the INCHR Management system.As recommended in the INCHR Capacity Gap Assessment report conducted by GANHRI, OHCHR facilitated the visit of two key officials of the Kenya National Commission on Human Rights (KNCHR) to Liberia to share experiences and best practices with INCHR’s BOC and Secretariat. The Kenyan delegation provided a report of their findings and recommendations. OHCHR and INCHR have laid a roadmap to implement the recommendations.OHCHR then supported INCHR to identify priority areas for action as recommended in both the GAHNRI report and the Kenya Human Rights Commission report.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

tag.narrative: 16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
